Not to mention amphibians, reptiles, birds, anthropological artifacts, meteorites, minerals and gems.  Only about five percent of the museum collection is actually on display.
How many storage areas are there?
Happy to be useful.  It's rare enough these days.  According to security, Beauregard put the Whittlesley crates in storage area 1012.
Thank you for taking the time to help us with this, Dr. Frock.
Fourth floor, West wing, but stay with your class.
Way cool.  Then you know where the dinosaurs are.
Evolutionary Biologist.  I study how life on earth evolved over millions of years.
Nothing.  I'm in third grade.  What's a revolutionary what ch'a ma' callit?
I'm an Evolutionary Biologist.  What do you do?
What do you do?
Yes, I do.
You work here?
You're color blind.
They were yellow!
They were green eyes and they were slit like a lizard's.
It had a long tongue, teeth this big and yellow eyes.
Like this.
And it snuffled the ground like a dog.
Well almost.  Depends which house.  It smelled like old hamburger, and it made this weird noise.
Not that big.
Big as a house.
We were just lost, okay?  And we went down this curvy staircase.  At the bottom was a big shadow.
I don't know.  But I think it's bad.
What is it?
Quiet!
Don't be a wuss.  Come on.
I don't want to go this way.
Chicken.  This is a great short cut.
We're not supposed to go back there.
Let's ditch and find them ourselves.
She's never going to take us to see the dinosaurs.  That lady said they were on the fourth floor.
This room sucks.
Keep the animal quiet.
Oh no.  I smell it.
Another storage room.
Jesus, what is this?
Quiet.
Oh... my... God!
Not on the map.  Looks like it connects with the city sewer.
It's alright.  I can tell by the way the dog's acting that whatever was out there is gone.  What is this place?
Come on.  Let's get back to the others.  We can't leave them alone.
Look.  It's Hobbes!  He's all right.
He's right.  Follow me.
There's something out there!  Let's go get it now!  That's why we came down here, isn't it?
Get back!  Now!
Argo!  Hobbes!
Holy mother, what is that?
Stop!
Heel Argo!  Hobbes!  Heel!
Shut them up!
Keep the light up.  I can't see.
They've got something.
Not yet.  Let's try the fork to the left.
The dogs have lost the scent, Mr. Pendergast.  Maybe we should head back.
Hard to read in this light.  The ink is so faded.
Okay.
Not today.  Besides, I think the director of the museum is expecting you.
How about lunch?
Got to finish this thesis sometime.
Yes, he's fine.  Greg... take care of yourself!
Is Dr. Frock safe!
Yes.  Whatever killed Beauregard may have lived on this plant.  When the crates were put in secure storage, they were out of reach.  The killer couldn't get them, so it got the next best thing.
Eats them?
Pendergast told me the killer extracts and eats the hypothalamus and thalamus of the victim's brains!
So what?
This is it.  This is what he, or it... is after!  The plant has high concentrations of the same hormones found in minute quantities in the human brain!
Try Weinstein's tropic hormone.
4-monoxytocin is... "A hormone secreted by the human hypothalamus gland."
What kind of hormones?
These plant fibers are loaded with hormones!
It's reptilian.
What kind of egg is it?
There's another possibility.  A lot of repeated base pairs could suggest a high level of genetic damage.
Lizard DNA and human DNA on the same strand?  Impossible.  The sample must be contaminated.
Turkish Gecko, I believe.  A lizard.
It's not mammalian, that's for sure. I think it's reptilian.
What do you make of it, Margo?
What's that?
Mbwun.
Someone's been murdered.  Not shot, strangled or stabbed, either.  Torn limb from limb.  There's talk of a psychotic killer or even an animal.
For once I'm glad you're rumor central.  What in the world is going on?
I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, but you know me.  Telegraph. Telephone.  Tell Kawakita.  I got the definitive word from Cuthbert's secretary.  This is Dr. Frock's last week.
That's impossible.
Frock's been fired.
What?
Margo, you haven't heard?
I have the species identification on these teeth.  We can extract DNA and start running tests on the extrapolator program.  Call Dr. Frock.  He wanted a demonstration.
But at what a price.
If I spent half the time on my Fractal Evolution thesis that I spend on this fly rod, I'd have my PhD.
I'm in town on a case.  Dropped by to see Vince and we thought we'd see the new display.
I'm so glad to see you.  What's the occasion?
You have to.  Do it now!
I can't!
He has to look here or I won't get a clear shot.  Call him, Margo.
Do it, quickly.  Please.  Aim for the eye.
I have to shoot.
Just like John.  He won't listen.
Whatever that thing is, we have to kill it!

You have to!  Listen!  All viruses pass on their own DNA.  Instruct the cells of the host to make more viruses!  This one was different.  It inserted a whole array of genes into John.  Reptile genes, sixty five million years old.  Those genes remade him!  It's not his fault!
I don't believe it.

That thing is John Whittlesley.  I should have seen it before!  The fibers are infected with a virus. You eat them, and the virus alters your DNA!  He became addicted to them in South America, followed the plants back to the states.  He probably entered the country as a man.  It would have taken several months for the change to take place. That's how he got from the boat to the museum!
What?
No!  Don't kill him!  Pendergast, you were right.  It's John!

Listen to me, Pendergast.  Mbwun's DNA is part homo sapien.  In primates, the eye is a direct path to the brain!  If you get a clean shot, there's only one place you can kill it.  Shoot it in the eye!
We're not going to make the storage room!
It's coming.  Run.
You smell that?
Oh God!  Help!
Help someone!
It's deceptively simple.  Like a Bruckner Symphony or a Matisse.
That's a ptarmigan, feigning a broken wing.  The bird pretends to be injured to draw the fox away from its nest!
The answer's right in front of us.
How?
We have to try and draw it off!
I think... for the pleasure of the kill.
For what?
No.  It's still hunting, but not for the hormones.
Then it won't go after the others?
I think... it means it's full.
It didn't want the fibers.  What does that mean?
Its eyesight is worse than I thought.  It couldn't see us.  And it couldn't smell us through the glass.
What happened?
It's scared of me.
What is it doing?
What are you going to do?
Hide quickly!
No.  The planetarium is in the next cell.  This is one of the fire doors...
Is there another way around?
Vince!
The planetarium!
That was D'Agosta.
Unlock one of the other storage rooms.  We're going upstairs.  We'll leave a trail back to 1012 and try to trap the monster in here.
You'd slow us down and put Margo in danger.

We have the fibers.  Don't you see? The creature is hungry.  It wants the hormones in these plants.  It would take hundreds of human brains to supply what's in these fibers.  We're just a poor substitute.  To make it stop hunting, we have to give it what it wants.
But what can we do?  Our guns are useless --
But this isn't the jungle!  This is New York.  How did it get here?  A thing like that crossed two continents.  It makes no sense!
It's not supernatural.  Mbwun is an animal.  Part lizard, part human, a genetic freak of some kind, like the half-goat, half-sheep they found last year in the jungles of Vietnam.
I don't know how to deal with this. It's hellish.  Like nothing I ever saw.  I'm not trained to deal with a monster, a supernatural creature like that.
That would fit.  It's nocturnal. Quick.  Come inside.
No.  A chromium alloy tipped .45 caliber bullet bounced off that thing's skull like a spit ball.  I think it was bothered by my light.
Wounded?
Gone.
You're not.  Where is it?
No.  I think I'm hallucinating.
Pendergast?  Are you all right?
We need someone to take us to the secure storage area.

When DNA is defective, it often uncontrollably replicates long repeating sequences of the same base pair.  Viruses can damage DNA.  So can radiation, certain chemicals.  Even cancer.  Let's let the G.S.E. sort it out.  I have to get started.  This will take several hours.
Genetic damage?
I don't know.  Mr. Pendergast.  Do me a favor.  Get me a DNA readout on that claw.
What was it?
All right.  This is hard for me.  I'm a scientist.  I like order and logic. Sometimes too much.  There's got to be an explanation.  There can't be an animal in there.  But I saw something.
They're all heavily armed.
I didn't imagine it.  I know what I saw.  Are you sure there are enough men in there?
Dr. Green...
All right.  If you're positive.
That's not what I saw.
Behind me.  Over there.
Where did you see it?
It's okay, I'm all right.  I remember now... It was an animal.  Something large!  I could smell it.  It was hunting me.  I saw two green eyes in the dark.
You were behind me?  Running after me?
I heard you calling and I ran after you, but you kept disappearing and I couldn't keep up.
I don't know.
What happened?
All right.  I'm as macho as you are. Perhaps.
I'm not sure.  We should split up. You take that hall and I'll take this one.
Where would we find it?
Would you mind showing it to me?
I don't know.  He sent back a statue that's supposed to be an exact representation.  But I've never seen it.  It's in the exhibit.
I don't think so.  I think we were meant to think it was Mbwun.  Did Whittlesley's monster have claws?
My God.  Then it was an animal.
Something came up in autopsy tonight.  Imbedded in Beauregard's body we found a claw.
I don't understand.
What if Whittlesley arrived on the tepui and no monster was there?  Was he desperate enough to create one?
No.  I'm all right.  I won't let this affect me anymore.  John wouldn't get help.  His ego endangered the lives of others.  His theory came first.
No one knows.  The Kothoga who live on the tepui are cannibals.
What happened?

Yes.  He developed his own theory that he called the Calisto Effect. It held that evolution wasn't always gradual or driven by natural selection.  The environment would sometimes cause sudden and grotesque changes which could result in a "monster species".  It made no sense. But he felt he had evidence that Mbwun was such a monster, living in isolation on the tepui for thousands of years.
A monster?
A legendary monster called Mbwun.
Tell me about the last expedition. What was he looking for?

He was afraid of himself.  He tried suicide once.  He was ill.  Manic depressive.  He had wild emotional highs and lows.  Not a happy affliction for a scientist.  He'd been revered in our community.  By the end he was a joke.
You were afraid of him, weren't you?
That was two years ago.  John was still in love with me.  He wouldn't leave me alone.
I ran an internet search on Dr. Whittlesley.  Got a list of his scholarly articles and the engagement announcement in the Times.  I also found a record of your restraining order.
How did you know that?
You were going to be married.
Yes.  Once.  We met at Columbia.  John held the Cadwalader Chair in Statistical Paleontology when I was a grad student there.
You loved him.
John couldn't have anything to do with a horrible thing like that.  He was a fine man despite his problems --
The people killed were mauled and their brains were eaten.  Just like Beauregard.  One part of the brain was extracted with surgical precision.  The hypothalamus and thalamus to be exact.
I don't understand.
Disappeared.  His body wasn't among the victims.
And John?

Dr. Whittlesley was last seen in Belem, Venezuela a week after the rest of his expedition disappeared. A taxi driver drove him to the harbor where he boarded a cargo boat.  That boat washed up in my district.  Everyone on board was killed.
You have time to talk?
If he were alive he'd have contacted me.
Maybe not.
Somehow, when all this happened... I knew it would come back to John.  Is he really dead?
No.  I came to talk about Dr. John Whittlesley.

With a DNA analysis from a fossil you can use this program to tell the species and sex of the animal, whether it was nocturnal, what it ate, how it hunted, how big it was...  You aren't here for a lesson in DNA.
How does it work?
An invention of mine.  It's a computer program designed to describe the characteristics of a given species from a reading of its DNA.  I call it the Genetic Sequence Extrapolator.
Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI. Forgive me.  I guess I was snooping. What is this?
It doesn't matter.  I'll make other arrangements.
You want to book the flight?
That's right.
I thought you were in a hurry.
Why wouldn't I?
I do have a fabulous rate on a cruise ship departing for Fiji tomorrow.  But you wouldn't want to do that.
You are a travel agent, aren't you?  "Doris"?  Your job is to help people travel.
It's the busy season.
A month.
I'm sorry.  I don't have anything for at least a month.
Today.
When do you want to leave, remembering, of course, you do lose a day on the way there?
One.
Viti Levu.  For how many?
I'm sorry, er...the biggest one.
Where in Fiji? What island?
Fiji.
Where exactly?
I want to book a flight to Fiji.
I'm sorry to keep you.  How can I help?
Do it!
He doesn't care.
Storm music...Wagner...
What music?
Cue music...
Sweep the harbor.
Why would we--
We're not watching the sea.
It's just a matter of time.
What have we missed?
I'm sure we'll get him on this next sweep.
He has to be on foot.  He has the world's most recognizable face.  He can't disappear.
All prop cars accounted for?
We've declared a curfew.  Everyone else is at first positions.
He gave it back to his father.
Give me a shot from Truman's ring.
He was tidying up his garbage.  I was going to call you.  But half-way through, he gave up and fell asleep.
What happened down there?
What's on the ClockCam?
What's to see?
Why wasn't I told?  Any unpredictable behavior has to be reported.  Is that the best shot we can get?
He moved down there after Meryl packed up and left.
Why is he in the basement?
No, hold back...
Close up?
Let's take another call.  London, England, you're on "Tru Talk."
We've learnt about life as Truman has and, despite the complaints of a minority, it's been an overwhelmingly positive experience, for Truman and for the viewing public.
The Hague for Christof...The Hague?...lost them.  Hollywood, California, you're on "Tru Talk."
I've been tempted.  But I think it's important to retain objectivity.  I wouldn't want to get emotionally caught up.
You've never actually met Truman, yourself.  Never thought about doing a cameo--playing a veterinarian, or a priest, something like that?

We accept the reality of the world with which we're presented.  As the show expanded, naturally we were forced to manufacture ways to keep Truman in Seahaven - demonstrating that every venture is accompanied by a risk.
Why do you feel that Truman's never come close to discovering the true nature of his world?
And it's all available in the "Truman" Show" catalogue.  Operators are standing by.
There's nothing on the show I don't use myself.
All products carefully chosen and tested by you for quality and aesthetic value.
Yes, everything you see on the show is for sale - from the actors' wardrobe, food products, to the very homes they live in--
No, of course not.  And since the show runs 24 hours a day with no commercial breaks the staggering profits are all generated from product placement.
People forget it takes the population of an entire country to keep the show running.
And the show now generates a yearly income equivalent to the gross national product of a small country.
That's correct.

Who knew that a show originally meant to last one year - "Bringing Up Baby" - would turn into a "cradle to grave" concept.  He is in fact the first child in the world to be legally adopted by a corporation.
In competition with five other unwanted pregnancies - the casting of a show determined by an air date - he was the one who arrived on cue.
Of course, his eagerness to leave his mother's womb also meant he was the one selected.
He was curious from birth - premature by two weeks, as if he couldn't wait to get started.
Let me demonstrate some examples.
We should remind viewers that Truman, especially as a child, presented a challenge for the production.
Istanbul, Turkey, you're on with master videographer, Christof.

As with our own lives, the only people he can't cast are his family.  Otherwise he has final approval, able to elevate an extra into a lead role as was the case with his only real friend, Marlon, or alternatively relegate a star to a bit player.
Of course, Truman has always been very much in on casting.
Certainly a nomination.
Are we talking Emmies?
Let's go to some of those viewers' calls.
We find many viewers leave him on all night for comfort.  Haven't you ever watched your child or your lover sleep?
But how do you account for the popularity of those eight hours a day when Truman sleeps?
Not only does he give us a glimpse of the truth, he gives us a glimpse of ourselves.
I prefer to think of it as a mirror.
A window onto the human condition?

We've become tired of watching actors give us phony emotions, bored with pyrotechnics and special effects.  While the world he inhabits is counterfeit, there's nothing fake about Truman himself.  No scripts, no cue cards.  It's not always Shakespeare but it's genuine.  That's how he can support an entire channel.
It has to be the reality.

But recent events have been so dramatic, it does raise the perennial question. What keeps us watching this one man twenty-four hours a day - eating, sleeping, working, sitting for hours in contemplation?

As you know ratings have never been our primary goal.  I imagine we'll lose those voyeurs only interested in witnessing Truman's latest torment.  However, I'm certain that our core audience will remain loyal.
Let's talk ratings.  "Truman" has always enjoyed top ten status but the huge surge over the last few days--how do you hope to sustain that audience now that Truman appears to have reconciled himself?
Of course.
Amnesia.
How do you intend to explain his twenty- two year absence?
That and a fat, new contract.
I understand he's hardly had a life of his own since he left the show.  How did you convince him--was it the opportunity to be close to Truman again?
Since Kirk started this whole crisis in Truman's life, I came to the conclusion that he was the only one who could end it.
--and certainly the first time that an intruder has been rewarded with a starring role.  I really must congratulate you on writing Kirk back in.  A master stroke.
--a dead one at that.
Of course, there hasn't been anything to compare with this - the first time an intruder has been a former cast member--
We have had our close calls in the past.

The catalyst for the recent dramatic events was of course Truman's father, Kirk, and his infiltration onto the show. Before we discuss that, it's worth reminding viewers that this isn't the first time someone from the outside world has tried to reach Truman.
Thank you.
Welcome.
--You never had a camera in my head.
Truman, I've watched you your whole life. I saw you take your first step, your first word, your first kiss.  I know you better than you know yourself.  You're not going to walk out that door--
I have a map.
You were real. That's what made you you so good to watch.
Nothing was real.
You're the star.
A show. Then who am I?
A show - that gives hope and joy and inspiration to millions.
The creator of what?
I'm the creator.
Who are you?
I can't believe he married Meryl on the rebound.
Because his mother got sick - very sick.  He couldn't leave her.  He's a kind boy, maybe too kind.
But why didn't he just follow her to Fiji?
Shhh!
The memory of who?
They removed all physical trace of her but they couldn't erase the memory.
What's he doing?
Guess I always thought they'd adopt.
Sure she would.
You think she'd go through with it?
Why not?
It's not gonna be his, you idiot.
How can they have a child?
I...I can't.
It's beautiful!  What are you waiting for?
I think I've studied enough.
Well, what do you want to do?
If we don't go now, it won't happen.
Right now?  We've got finals tomorrow.
Now.
Actually, I'm free Sunday.
Saturday?
No.
No?  Really?  Good, I mean, I thought possibly a pizza.  How about Friday?
No...I, er.
You have a boyfriend?  Of course you do.
I'm sorry.  It's not up to me.
It's okay.  I probably wouldn't talk to me either.
--I'm not allowed to talk to you.
I'm Truman, Truman Burbank--
That's right.  Lauren.
Lauren, right?
Oh, yes.
You take Japanese.
The thing that started all of this.
What's that?
Not the whole thing, Truman.  You were right about one thing.
So what are you saying, Marlon, the whole thing has been in my head--?
And the last thing I'd ever do is lie to you. Think about it, Truman, if everybody's in on it, I'd have to be in on it too. I'm not in on it, because there is no it.
This is different.  Everybody seems to be in on it.

It's a lot of world for one man.  You sure that's not wishful thinking, you wishing you'd made something more of yourself? Christ, Truman, who hasn't sat on the John and had an imaginary interview on "Seahaven Tonight"?  Who hasn't wanted to be somebody?
I don't know what to think, Marlon. Maybe I'm going out of my mind, but I get the feeling that the world revolves around me somehow.
Truman?  It's me, Marlon.  I need to talk to you.
Stay where you are!
Really?
Just between you and me, Marlon, I'm going away for a while.
That's the "Big Guy".  Quite a paintbrush he's got.
Yeah...
I went all over but I never found a place like this.  Look at that sunset, Truman.  It's perfect.
When you were hauling chickens for Kaiser Poultry, what was the furthest you ever went off the island?
No.
Things.  Things that doesn't fit.  Maybe I'm being set up for something. You ever feel like that, Marlon?  Like your whole life has been building to something?
What exactly?
This is where it started.
What're we doing here, Truman?
I've got to show you something.
I told you I can't.
Could be.  Beard looks phony.  It's when I'm unpredictable.  They can't stand that.  That's why we've got to get out of here.  Can you come with me?
How about them?
It's hard to tell.  They look just like regular people.
Who?
I think he's alive.  I'll tell you about it later.  I'm definitely being followed.
Your Dad?!
I think it's got something to do with my dad.
No.  Truman, if this is another one of your fantasies...
There's no point in trying to explain it, but a lot of strange things have been happening - elevators that don't go anywhere, people talking about me on the radio, you know what I mean?
Mixed up? Mixed up in what?
I think I'm mixed up in something.
Are you okay?  You look like shit.
I'm onto something, Marlon - something big.
Sorry, I'm way behind.
I've got to talk to you.
--Truman, what are you doing here?
Marlon--
I can't tonight.
Sure.  It's halogen.  Shame it didn't hit you - you could've sued.  You coming for a drink?
You really think it could've dropped off an airliner?
Trust me.
You think so?

I figured, what's the point?  I knew I'd just be taking my problems with me.  Once the kids came along, it made me look at Seahaven with new eyes.  I realized, what the hell could be better than this?  I'm telling you.  What you really need is someone to carry on the "Burbank" name.
Yeah, what happened?
Truman, you know, I did think about moving away one time.
Spare room - I can start thinking about selling up...and I'll be gone. Up and away on that big steel bird. I'm going, don't you worry about that.
Nursery?

It's not that simple.  Takes money, planning.  You can't just up and go.  Oh, I'm going to do it, don't worry about that.  I've just got to move slow.  Pick my moment.  Bonus time's just around the corner.  Soon as I finish the...
So when are you leaving?
See here, this is us.  All the way round here, Fiji.  You can't get any further away before you start coming back.  Y'know, there are still islands in Fiji where no human has ever set foot.
Outta my job, outta Seahaven, off this island...out!
Yeah?  Outta what?
I'm thinking of getting out, Marlon.
--Truman, you're gonna be late!

--What are my plans now? Well, next I'm thinking of tackling the Yuba River in an authentic canoe from the Algonquin tribe. --I'm talking about the north fork, a class five rapid - only I'm not going down the Yuba, I'm going up. Do you honestly think for one minute I'd go back to some dreary office to rubber stamp meaningless documents...do you?
Truman, stop it!
No.  You said, "Do something."  Who were you talking to?  Tell me!
You're the one talking to the walls!
Who were you talking to?!
Do something...
Stop this now.  I'll do it.  I swear.
You're part of this, aren't you?!
You're having a nervous breakdown, that's what's happening.
What the hell has that got to do with anything?  Tell me what's happening?!
I've tasted other cocoas.  This is the best.
--What the hell are you talking about?!
Why don't I make you some of this new Mococoa Drink?  All natural.  Cocoa beans from the upper slopes of Mount Nicaragua. No artificial sweeteners--
That's not true.
Why do you want to have a child with me? You can't stand me.
Let me get you some help, Truman.  You're not well.
So we just eat into our savings, is that the idea?  I'd better call your mother when we get there.  She'll be worried sick - I don't know how she's going to take this.
I've got my Seahaven Bankcard.
So what do we do for money when we get to New Orleans?
I'm sure they're just exaggerating.
Truman, what about that sign?
I bet you did.
Truman, I took the "hypocrite" oath!
Uhuh.  There's no accident.  It's just more stalling.
There's been an accident, Truman.
It's hard to go places, isn't it?
I think I'd like a little company.
Let me out, Truman.  You're not right in the head.  You want to destroy yourself, you do it on your own!
I've changed my mind again.  What's New Orleans like this time of year?  Mardi Gras.  Or let's just see where the road takes us.
Truman, that was our house!
Should I?
You blaming me for the traffic?
Blocked at every turn.  Beautifully synchronized, don't you agree?
Truman, I think I'm going to throw up.
Because I never have.  That's why you go places, isn't it?
So why do you want to go?
That's right.  I do, don't I?
You hate gambling.
Where shall we go?  Where shall we go? Spontaneity is what it's all about. Forget Fiji.  We can't very well drive to Fiji, can we?  What about Atlantic City?
What?!
Let's go now.
You're upset because you want to go to Fiji.  Is that it?
Are you listening to a word I'm saying?
--we need more charcoal.
I won't be here Sunday.
I invited Marlon and Rita for a barbeque Sunday.  I thought I'd make my potato salad.  Remind me--
Put some butter on it--or ice?
--you're a nurse, aren't you?
I don't know--
What do I do?
Oh, my God!
Arrah!
Surgery.  The elevator disaster downtown on the news last night.  Cable snapped, a car dropped ten floors.  Non-union contractors.  Monsters.  We're starting with an amputation.
What's the hurry?
I'm sorry, I'm late.
I have to talk with you.  But not here.  Let's go for a walk.
See you in a minute, sweetheart.
Good night, Mother.
I'll take you home, Angela.  Why don't you leave those with us for a while?
I still want to look over a couple of things.
Come on, Truman.  Haven't you studied enough?
I'm not hungry.
I made macaroni.
What did you want?
Your mother called.  You shouldn't upset her like that.
How do you know?
I know.
Fixing the mower.  I saw my father today.
What're you doing down here?
I think I'm going to stay up for a while.
This'll pass.  Everybody thinks like this now and then.  Come to bed.
That can wait.  I want to get away.  See some of the world.  Explore.
I thought we were going to try for a baby.  Isn't that enough of an adventure?
It'd be an adventure.
We're mortgaged to the eyeballs, Truman. There's the car payments.  Are we just going to walk away from our financial obligations?
Maybe I feel like a teenager.
And then what, Truman?  We'd be back to where we were five years ago.  You're talking like a teenager.
--We could bum around the world for a year on that.
Every time you and Marlon--
--I figure we could scrape together eight thousand.
Oh, God.
I've been thinking--
Where have you been?
Did something happen today?
I won't be late.
I was hoping we could have a special evening.
A man tripped and fell on a chainsaw.  We got three of his fingers back on.
How did it go today?
Gee, that's great.
Hi, honey.  Look at this.  It's a "Chef's-Mate."  Dicer, slicer and peeler in one.  Never needs sharpening. Dishwasher safe.
They're...  perfect.  Thank you.
Well, what do you think?
It's a surprise.
What's that?
Truman, you're gonna be late!

...personally I think the unconquered south face is the only one worth scaling...of course it's a 20,000 foot sheer wall of ice but then when did that ever stop me before?...Naturally, I intend to make the ascent without the benefit of oxygen but also without crampons or even an ice pick...risks?... ...sure I'm aware of the risks--why else do you think I would spend seven years as an adjuster in a life insurance company...?
Things always do--when you look back.
It looks so small.
Hold on a minute, dear.  Here's us at Mount Rushmore.  You remember, Truman--when Dad was still with us - that was quite a drive.  You slept all the way there.
We ought to be getting you back, Mother.
You know he was an only child, like you.  I know how bad you feel about what happened--sailing into that storm.  But I don't blame you, Truman.  I never have.
I'm telling you, if it wasn't him, it was his twin.  Did Dad have a brother?
--Darling--
They never found Dad's body--maybe somehow--
About time they started cleaning up the trash Downtown.  We don't want to end up like the rest of the country.
It was Dad, I swear, dressed like a homeless man.  And you know what else was really strange?  A businessman and a woman with a little dog appeared from nowhere and forced him onto a bus.
It doesn't sound insane, Truman.  I swear I see him ten times a week--in a hundred faces.  I almost hugged a perfect stranger in the salon last Thursday.
I feel certain my condition runs in the family.  Can't this wait, dear?
I spend half my life out in the sun, Mother, why would I need vitamin D?
You look very pale, Truman.  Are you taking your vitamin D's?
I've got something to tell you.  You'd better sit down.
You know surprises aren't good for me. You should really call before you come over, dear.
Oh, just so.
How's your hip?
Well, I made it through another night.
How are you, Mother?
Fine.  I'll tell her.
You got it.
When you get to Fiji?
Tell her, tell her...I had to go to Fiji. I'll call her when I get there.
I'll try.
Sure.  Okay.  Fine.  Can you pass on a message?
I'm afraid that's impossible--she's in pre-op.
I'm looking for my wife--Nurse Burbank. It's important.
You're welcome, Truman.
Well, thank you for your help.
The whole area's being evacuated.
Is there any way around?
Leak at the plant.  They had to shut her down.
Now what?
You must listen.  Everybody's pretending, Truman.
I don't understand.
--It doesn't matter.  Everybody knows about it.  They know everything you do. The point is, you got scared.
Were you there--how do you know?
--And your teacher said, "You're too late, Truman.  There's nothing left to explore."
--How do you know about that?
Just listen.  You remember when you were a little boy, you stood up in class and said you wanted to be an explorer like Magellan--
There's no one here.
They're going to stop me talking to you.
Who?
They're coming.  Any minute.
You can count on it.
See you tomorrow, Truman.
I'd ask for identification.
Tyrone, what if I said I didn't want meatball today?
Good.  Good.
Not bad.  I just won the State Lottery.
How's it going, Truman?
You're not FBI agents.
Well, we're FBI agents.
We don't even know you.
I think you better tell us.
You're not supposed to talk about it? Who told you that?
Not supposed to talk about it.
Yeah.
Do you live around here?
Sorry. Don't have one.
Why don't you go home to the old lady --
Does what?
I think that about does it, Spooky.

What do I do.  I'm a key figure in an ongoing government charade. An annoyance to my superiors. A joke among my peers. "Spooky," they call me. Spooky Mulder. Whose sister was abducted by aliens when he was a kid. Who now chases little green men with a badge and a gun, shouting to the heavens and anyone who'll listen that the fix is in. That our government's hip to the truth and a part of the conspiracy. That the sky is falling and when it hits it's gonna be the shitstorm of all time.
What do you do?
A woman?  Work.
Yup.
Poopy day?
Me?
I need your clothes, Byers.
They took her --
You called 911. Except the call was intercepted.
Scully had a violent reaction to a bee sting --
When was that?
They gave you a craniotomy to relieve the pressure from a subdural hematoma. But you've been unconscious since they brought you in.
Penetration but not perforation.
You were shot in the head. The bullet broke the flesh on your right brow and glanced off your temporal plate.
What am I doing here?

Most of what I find in here is lacking a coherent picture of an organization with an attributable motive. I realize you're very lucky to be alive Agent Scully. The ordeal you've endured has clearly affected you -- though the holes in your account leave this panel with little choice but to delete these references from our final report to the Justice Department. Until which time hard evidence becomes available that would give us cause to pursue such an investigation.
No, they don't.

Well...where would you like me to start? Antarctica is a long way from Dallas, Agent Scully. I can't very well submit a report to the Attorney General that alleges the links you've made here. Bees and corn crops do not quite fall under the rubric of domestic terrorism.
What is it you find incredible?
Agent Mulder.
Working with?
I hope to. We're working to develop this evidence --
Nothing completely conclusive --
And you have conclusive evidence of this? Something to tie this claim of yours to the crime --
Yes. I know.
-- those are very serious allegations, Agent Scully --
That the bombing in Dallas may have been to destroy the bodies of those firemen, so their deaths and the reason for them wouldn't have to be explained --
Are you going to let us in on what exactly you're trying to prove --
Yes.
You've been back to Dallas?
Evidence of what?
I apologize for making you wait -- I've brought some new evidence with me --
Special Agent Scully --
They seemed to buy our story about the Hanta virus. You'll make sure the families are taken care of financially, along with a sizeable donation to the community.  Maybe a small roadside memorial.
Of what?
Tell them he was trying to save the young boy's life, and that he died heroically like the other firemen.
This man's family will want to see the body laid to rest.
Incinerate it. Like the others.
And if it's unsuccessful?
No. No...we need to try our vaccine on it.
Do you want me to destroy this one, too? Before it gestates?
The developing organism is using his life energy, digesting bone and tissue. We've just slowed the process.
How can this be?
Technically and biologically, though he'll never recover.
This man's still alive.
Heat, I think. The coincident invasion of a host, the fireman, and an environment that raised his basic body temperature above ninety eight point six.
Brought on by what?
We brought the atmosphere back down to freezing in order to control the development, which is nothing like we've ever seen.
Yes.
You've got something to show me.
Kurtzweil, we think.
Who?
Mulder was in Dallas when we were trying to dispose of evidence. He's gone back there again. Someone has tipped him.
Do they know?
There are complications.
My lateness may have well been absence. A course has already been taken.
Into what?
Its effect on the host has changed. The virus no longer just invades the brain as a controlling organism. It's developed a way to modify the host body.
Strughold. He's just gotten on a plane in Tunis.
Who called this meeting?
Is it an emergency?
We have a situation. The members are assembling.
Yes.
No. Don't bother.
You want a call if we turn up Kurtzweil?
Yeah, I had an appointment for a pelvic examination.
You looking for him for some other reason?
Selling naked pictures of little kids over his computer.
What's that?
Feds are looking for him, too.  Real nice business he's got, huh?
Looking for him for what?
I'm looking for him.
You got some kind of business with him?
Is this Dr. Kurtzweil's residence?
Show you right on a map.
You said you knew the location of the archeological site where these were found.
No. Just fossils, far as I know.
Have you examined them?
Some bone fragments came up in the sift this morning. We thought there'd been another fatality, but we found out FEMA had recovered them from an archeological site out of town.
Was there anything in those offices that didn't go to D.C.?
We weren't expecting to find those remains, of course. They went right off to Washington.
I'm looking for anything out of the ordinary. Maybe something from the FEMA offices where the bodies were found.
And why do you think it is you're standing here talking to me? These people don't make mistakes, Agent Mulder.
Your ass? I just got chased across Texas by two black helicopters.
You'd be shit out of luck if not for me. You saw what you saw because I led you to it. I'm putting my ass on the line for you.
You're a liar. You lied to me to gather information for you. For your goddamn books. Didn't you?
I told you -- he and I were old friends --
You didn't know my father --
I've been using you?!
You've been using me --
Yeah, well I don't have them all.
You told me you had answers.
Your guess?
That would be my guess.
A transportation system. Transgenic crops. The pollen genetically altered to carry a virus.
What do you think?
What did it look like?
-- You saw this experiment?
I'm not sure. A virus --
What?
Yes. On the Texas border. Some kind of experiment. Something they excavated was brought there in tanker trucks.
You found something?
You can't.
How can I reach you?
Something's gone wrong -- something unanticipated. Go back to Dallas and dig. Or you're only going to find out like the rest of the country, Agent Mulder. When it's too late.
And they tell me I'm paranoid.

I think you know. The timetable has been set. It will happen on a holiday, when people are away from their homes. When our elected officials are at their resorts or out of the country. The President will declare a state of emergency, at which time all federal agencies, all government will come under the power of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. FEMA, Agent Mulder. The secret government.
Negotiating with whom?

The plague to end all plagues, Agent Mulder. A silent weapon for a quiet war. The systematic release of an indiscriminate organism for which the men who will bring it on still have no cure. They've been working on this for fifty years. While the rest of the world was fighting gooks and commies these men have been secretly negotiating a planned Armageddon.
A plague?

What killed those men can't be identified in simple medical terms. My god, we can't even wrap our minds around something as obvious as HIV. We have no context for what killed those men, or any appreciation of the scale in which it will be unleashed in the future. Of how it will be transmitted; of the environmental factors involved.
I'll know soon enough.
What killed them I won't even write about. I tell you, they'd do more than just harass me. They have the future to protect.
What killed those men?
When we were young men in the military, your father and I were recruited for a project. They told us it was biological warfare. A virus. There were rumors about its origins.
What was it?
Are you saying it wasn't such a small outbreak?

And are you familiar with FEMA? What the Federal Emergency Management Agency's real power is? FEMA allows the White House to suspend constitutional government upon declaration of a national emergency. To create a non-elected government. Think about that.  What is an agency with such broad sweeping power doing managing a small viral outbreak in suburban Texas?
It was a deadly virus spread by field mice in the Southwest U.S. several years ago.
According to the newspaper, FEMA had been called out to manage an outbreak of the Hanta virus. Are you familiar with the Hanta virus, Agent Mulder?
You said the firemen and the boy were found in the temporary offices of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Why?
I picked up the historical document of the venality and hypocrisy of the American government. The daily newspaper.
How?
I was right about Dallas. Wasn't I, Agent Mulder?
I don't either, but it sure sells books.
Dr. Kurtzweil, I'm not interested in bigoted ideas about race or genocide. I don't believe in the Elders of Zion, the Knights Templar, the Bilderburg Group or in a oneworld Jew run government --
You know my work?
You mean that apocalyptic trash you write? I knew your name was familiar. I just didn't know why.
For what? Because I'm a dangerous man. Because I know too much about the truth.
They want to discredit you -- for what?
What is it? Kiddie porn again? Sexual battery of a patient? I've had my license taken away in three states.
Not according to the men in blue.
See this bullshit...? Somebody knows I'm talking to you.
Do you?
I think you're full of shit.
And one little boy.
You're saying they destroyed an entire building to hide the bodies of three firemen...?
Michaud was a patriot. The men he's loyal to know their way around Dallas. They blew that building to hide something. Maybe something even they couldn't predict.
Michaud was a twenty-two year veteran of the bureau --
That's what I'm saying.
Before the bomb went off?
Those people were already dead.

No. They put the bomb in the building across the street because it DID have federal offices. The Federal Emergency Management Agency had a provisional medical quarantine office there. Which is where the bodies were found. But that's the thing...
The Federal Building was too well guarded.
What's the question nobody's asking? Why that building? Why not the Federal Building?
He just let it explode.
S.A.C. Darius Michaud never tried or intended to defuse the bomb.
And what's that?
Well, if you've got something to tell me, you've got as long as it takes me to hail a cab...
I came on my own. After reading about the bombing in Dallas.
Who sent you?
I'm a doctor, but I think I mentioned that. OB-GYN.
You a reporter?
Heard you come here now and again. Figured you'd be needing a little drinky tonight.
How'd you find me?
Old friend of your father's.
I know the name. Why?
My name's Kurtzweil. Dr. Alvin Kurtzweil.
Yeah, I did.
You follow me out here for a reason?
No. I've been watching your career for a good while. Back when you were just a promising young agent -- before that.
Do I know you?
Standing around holding your yank while bombs are exploding.
How's that?
Yes you can. You're going to make it, Scully.
I can't go any farther.
You got me. But I think I know what they did with Jimmy Hoffa.
Where are we?
We've got to keep moving.
Hang on. I'm going to get you out of here.
Cold...
I've got no allergy. Something... this... Mulder... I think... I think you should call an ambulance.
Scully --
No -- it's --
I think you're in anaphylactic shock --
...my pulse feels thready and I've got a funny taste in the back of my throat.
Something's wrong...  I'm having -- lancinating pain -- my chest. My... motor functions are being affected. I'm...
Scully...
I think... something stung me.
What? What happened?

You saved me, Scully.  As different and frustrating as it's been sometimes, your goddamn strict rationalism and science have saved me a thousand times; have kept me honest and made me whole. I owe you so much, Scully, and you owe me nothing.  I don't want to do this without you. I don't know if I can. If I quit now, they win.
Why was I assigned to you? To debunk your work. To reign you in. To shut you down.
You don't Mulder -- you've never needed me. I've only held you back.  I've got to go.
I need you on this, Scully --
I'm contacting the state board Monday to file medical reinstatement papers --
Just like that --
I have. I did. It's done.
After what you saw last night -- after all you've seen -- you can't just walk away --
You're on the verge, Mulder -- please don't do this to me --
We're close to something here -- we're on the verge --
I can, Mulder. I debated whether or not to even tell you in person, because I knew --
You can't quit, Scully.
I already gave Skinner my letter of resignation.
Salt Lake City, Utah. Transfer effective immediately.
What? What's wrong?
I don't know.
Where'd they go?
Come on!
What are you doing?
Run.
Yeah...?
Scully....?
Maybe. Maybe not.
I hear the humming. Like electricity. High voltage maybe.
You hear that?
For the purpose of what?
Cool in here. Temperature's being regulated.
Not unless those are giant Jiffy Pop containers out there.
Any thoughts on why anybody'd be growing corn in the middle of the desert?
Very weird.
This is weird, Mulder.
I have no idea.
What do you think it is?
Pounding down some dirt road in the middle of the night. Chasing some elusive truth on a dim hope, only to find myself standing right where I am right now: at another dead end --
Been where?
I don't believe this. I don't fucking believe this.  Y'know, I've been here... I've been here one too many times with you, Mulder.
It may be extraterrestrial.
Mulder --
This virus -- it...
What do you mean by haul?  What are you not telling me here?
Yeah, well they may this one.
They haul gas in tanker trucks, they haul oil in tanker trucks -- they don't haul viruses in tanker trucks.
That bomb in Dallas was allowed to go off, to hide something: bodies infected with a virus you detected yourself.
-- of what exactly?!
We're not chasing trucks, we're chasing evidence --

I've got to be in Washington D.C. in eleven hours for a hearing -- the outcome of which might possibly affect one of the biggest decisions of my life. And here I am standing out in the middle of nowhere Texas, chasing phantom tanker trucks.
What?
This is great. This is fitting.
Hey, I was right about the bomb, wasn't I?
I don't know why I think they went right.
You think they went left?
We've got two choices. One of them is wrong.
Where would they be going?
About a hundred miles of nothing in each direction.
What are my choices?
That's the first question to answer, if we're going to find them.
And where are they going with it?
I don't know, Mulder.
Unmarked tanker trucks... what are archaeologists hauling out in tanker trucks?
No irrigation system. Somebody's covering their tracks.
All the equipment is brand new.
Ground's dry about an inch down. Somebody just laid this down. Very recently, I'd say.
It looks pretty green for this climate.
This looks like new grass to you?
No.  It didn't show up on any of the immunohistochemical tests --
And you've never seen anything like that?
The bone was porous, as if the virus of the causative microbe were digesting it.
You're sure the fossils you looked at showed the same signs of deterioration you saw in the fireman's body in the morgue?
I don't see any evidence of an archeological or any other kind of digsite. Not even a sewer or a storm drain.
This is where he marked on the map, Scully. Where he says those fossils were unearthed.
He didn't mention a park.
That I don't know. But if it's through simple contact of blood to blood, and if it doesn't respond to conventional treatments, it could be a serious health threat.
How was it contracted?

Something I couldn't show to anyone else. Not without more information. And not without causing the kind of attention I'd just as soon avoid right now.  The virus those men were infected with contains a protein coat I've never seen before. What it did to them it did extremely fast. And unlike the AIDS virus or any other aggressive strain, it survives very nicely outside the body.
What did you find?
I wasn't planning on it. Particularly after spending a half hour in cold storage this morning. But I got a better look at the blood and tissue samples I took from the firemen.

Mulder -- I can't -- I'm already way past the point of common sense here --
-- I'll have you back for it, Scully. Maybe with evidence that could blow that meeting away.

I need you there with me. I need your expertise on this. The bomb we found was meant to destroy those bodies and whatever they were infected by.
Mulder --
Scully -- listen to me. I'm going home, then I'm booking a flight to Dallas. I'm getting you a ticket, too.

Evidence of a massive infection.

You're telling me the cause of death on the report is false. That this man didn't die from an explosion, or from flying debris.
And there's been no autopsy performed. There's no Y incision here; no internal exam.
There's some kind of cellular breakdown. It's completely edematous.
It's like jelly.

According to this tag.

Just get dressed. I'll explain on the way.

I thought you may have gotten drunk and decided to come here to talk me out of quitting.

No.
I wake you?
There's really no reason left for me to stay anymore.  Maybe you should ask yourself if your heart's still in it, too.
You're... quitting?

They're not doing this, Mulder.  I left behind a career in medicine because I thought I might make a difference at the FBI. When they recruited me they told me women made up nine percent of the bureau. I felt this was not an impediment, but an opportunity to distinguish myself. But it hasn't turned out that way. And now, if I were to be transferred to Omaha, or Wichita or some field office where I'm sure I could rise, it just doesn't hold the interest for me it once did. Not after what I've seen and done.
This isn't about you, Scully. They're doing this to me.
Because they wanted me to invalidate your work, your investigations into the paranormal. But I think this goes deeper than that.

I think you must have an idea. They cited a history of problems relating back to 1993.
Why?
I meet with the OPR day after tomorrow for remediation and reassignment...

They're trying to divide us on this, Scully. We can't let them.
All I told them was the truth.
Whatever you told them in there, you don't have to protect me.
-- Mulder! Get in the car!
Something's not right...
Mulder. Move away from the door. We're coming through it.
Scully?
Hang on. I'm gonna get you out of there.
...thirteen fifty six...
Thirteen fifty nine, thirteen fifty eight, thirteen fifty seven...
Mulder? Tell me this is a joke.
Nice try, Mulder.
Scully, get somebody to open this door.
I'm in the vending room.
Where are you, Mulder?
Scully, I found the bomb.
Scully...
Something sweet.
Alright... what'll it be: Coke, Pepsi? A saline IV?
I just did. You're buying.
Panic? Have you ever seen me panic, Scully?
I saw your face, Mulder. There was a moment of panic.
Oh yeah. Had you big time.
No you didn't.
Had you.
It's locked?
Now what?
What do you say we call in a bomb threat for Houston. I think it's free beer night at the Astrodome.
You've got to quit looking for what isn't there. They've closed the X-Files. There's procedure to be followed here. Protocol.
How's that?
I know you're bored in this assignment, but unconventional thinking is only going to get you into trouble now.

The element of surprise, Scully. Random acts of unpredictability. If we fail to anticipate the unforeseen or expect the unexpected in a universe of infinite possibilities, we find ourselves at the mercy of anyone or anything that cannot be programmed, categorized or easily referenced...
Jesus, Mulder...
What happened to playing a hunch?
Mulder...?

Mulder... when a terrorist bomb threat is called in, the logical purpose of providing this information is to allow us to find the bomb. The rational object of terrorism is to promote terror. If you'd study model behavioral pattern in virtually every case where a threat has turned up an explosive device. If we don't act in accordance with that data -- if you ignore it as we have done -- the chances are great that if here actually is a bomb we might not find it. Lives could be lost --
I think they have that covered.
I know that. But the threat was called in for the Federal Building across the street.
You're looking for a bomb.
I've just climbed twelve floors. I'm hot and thirsty and I'm wondering, to be honest, what I'm doing here.
What's wrong, Scully?
No. I haven't.
Did you find something?
I'm on the roof.

Mulder -- it's me --
Thank you.

They can patch you in through the switchboard.

General McAddie's.

We're going to the morgue.

I know.  Agent Scully reported your suspicions to OPR. On the basis of her report, I sent techs over to S.A.C. Michaud's apartment. They picked up PSTN residues on his personal effects consistent with the construction of the vending machine device in Dallas.
Whoever they are -- this goes right back to Dallas -- it goes right back to the bombing --
She's missing. We've been unable to locate her or the vehicle they took her in.
Where's Scully?!
Agent Mulder --
Agent Scully says it was she who ordered you out of the building. That you wanted to go back.
I breached protocol. I broke contact with the S.A.C. I ignored a primary tactical rule and left him alone with the device.
She's in there right now saying the same thing about you.
-- if they want someone to blame, they can blame me. Agent Scully doesn't deserve this.
-- if it looks bad, it's bad for the FBI --
But it's not the lives we saved. It's the lives we didn't.
Agent Mulder -- we both know that if you and Agent Scully hadn't taken the initiative to search the adjacent building, you could have multiplied the fatalities by a hundred --
And they want to blame us?

You don't see what's going on here, do you?  There's four hundred million dollars in damage to the city of Dallas. Lives have been lost. No suspects have been named. So the story being shaped is this could have been prevented. That the FBI didn't do its job.
She was with me.
-- They're asking her for a narrative. They want to know why she was in the wrong building.
About what?
Sit down, they're still talking to Agent Scully.
My life is over.  Go.
What about you?
Find Agent Scully. Save her. Only her science can save the future.
What alien environment?

The vaccine you hold is the only defense against the virus. Its introduction into an alien environment may have the power to destroy the delicate plans we've so assiduously protected for the last fifty years.  Or it may not.
How?
You have precious little time. What I've given you the alien colonists have no idea exists. You hold in your hand the power to end the project.
Driver.
Let me out. Stop the car.
Dr. Kurtzweil is in the trunk.
Where is he?
As your father knew, things need to be sacrificed to the future.
What happened to Kurtzweil?
I thought it only fair you should know, given how hard you've worked.

The only true survivors of the viral holocaust will be those immune to it: those vaccinated against it and human/alien hybrids. Your father arranged for your sister's abduction. He allowed her to be taken to an alien hybrid program, so that she would survive. As a clone.  He had different hopes for you. That you would uncover the truth about the Project. That you would stop it. That you would fight the future.
But... he sacrificed his own daughter. My sister, Samantha.

Imagine our surprise when they began to gestate. My group has been working cooperatively with the alien colonists, facilitating their programs. To give us access to the virus. In false hope we might be able to secretly find a cure. So that we might save ourselves, as the last of the species.  Your father wisely refused to believe this, choosing hope over selfishness. Hope is the only future he had: his children,  The only future any of us have.
That's why you bombed the building. The infected firemen, the boy --
Until Dallas, we believed the virus was simply a controlling organism. That mass infection would make us a slave race.

Your aliens, Agent Mulder, your little green men, first landed here millions of years ago. Those that didn't leave have been laying dormant underground since the last Ice Age. In the form of an evolved pathogen. Waiting to be reconstituted when the alien race from which it came returns to colonize the planet. Using us as hosts. Against this we have no defense. Nothing but a weak vaccine.  Do you see why it was kept secret? Why even the best men -- men like your father -- could not let the truth be known?
What do you mean, walked?
Aids, the ebola virus -- on the evolutionary scale they are newborns. This virus walked the planet long before the dinosaurs.
No! For God sake you've got it all backwards.
This is what you've been conspiring to conceal? A disease?
A simple, unstoppable lifeform. What is a virus but a colonizing force that cannot be defeated? Living in a cave, underground, until it mutates. And attacks.
A virus?
No. Though I have no way to prove otherwise. The virus is extraterrestrial. We know very little about it, except that it is the original inhabitant of this planet.
You're lying.
A weak vaccine against the virus Agent Scully has been infected with. It must be administered with ninety six hours.
What is it?
I want to know where Scully is.
I think of it as an agreement. A word your father liked to use.
About the conspiracy?
I'm quite prepared to tell you everything, though there isn't much you haven't guessed.
Yes.
Is she alive?
I have answers for you.
Where's Scully?

Mr. Mulder.

You need not kill a man to destroy him.
You can't kill Mulder. He's got too much light on him.
And Mulder?
No one believes Kurtzweil or his books. He's a toiler. A crank.
We've allowed this man his freedom. His books have actually helped us to facilitate plausible denial. Has he outlived his usefulness to us?
Well, without a cure for the virus, we're nothing more than digestives anyway.
Our vaccine may have no effect!
Cooperation is our only chance of saving ourselves.
And if it doesn't? By cooperating now we're but beggars to our demise! Our ignorance was in cooperating with the Colonists at all.

Let me remind you who is the new race. And who is the old.  What could be gained by withholding anything from them; By pretending to ignorance? Our knowledge may forestall their plans to step up the timetable. To start Colonization early.
In hope of what? Learning that it's true?! That we are nothing more than digestives for the creation of a new race of alien lifeforms?!
We're going to tell them what we've found. What we've learned. Turn over a body infected with the gestating organism.
This isn't Colonization, it's spontaneous repopulation. All our work... if it's true, then they've been using us all along. We've been laboring under a lie!
The geometry of mass infection presents certain conceptual re-evaluations for us. About our place in their Colonization.
My god...
We've been forced to reassess our role in Colonization by new facts of biology which have presented themselves.
More concerns than that?
I'm sorry. My grandson fell and broke his leg.
We began to worry. Some of us have traveled so far, and you are the last to arrive.
Give a kiss to Edward.
...give a kiss to Edward.

I'll come by tomorrow after work.  With dinner.

Yes mother.

No.
You're sure?  Any more nightmares?

And he might blame you for terrifying him.  That one moment could erase all you've accomplished.  And if that happened, the trust he has in you is gone.
I'd be there for him.
Yes, but, you're a willing participant. Picture Edward in a strange place, lost, frightened...
I do it all the time!
If we reverse the feed and bring Edward into your mind, it could be devastating for him.  Imagine the shock of suddenly existing in a whole other world.
It could take years for me to get past the barriers he's created.
I've heard this argument before.  It's not happening.
He creates the obstacles, he decides which games to play.

Miriam...
I don't want to find out.

I don't know.  I think it does.  You know, Catherine... If you ever want to talk about it.  What happened to Stargher.  That last time.

Well look at that.
Good for them.
Yep.  Eloped.
I heard Julia and John got married.

You sure about this?
Give her a minute.  Hello, Valentine.
That went well.

COME ON!

Where the hell are we?

Little boy?!  That's him!
He wants us to follow.  The little boy...
Like hell "wait."
Wait...
Okay, okay...
Remember, Julia Hickson is priority number one.  Nothing else matters.  Find out where she is.
Yes.  I am.
You're sure of that?
A child can experience abuse worse than Charlie's.  And grow up to be someone who would never, ever hurt another living thing.
Tell me.
What difference does it make...?
What happened?
What happened to Charles Gish?
Maybe this is a big fucking waste of time.
If you believe that.
Evil.

Not Stargher, not really.  He's split himself right down the middle. Good/evil, right/wrong, merciful/cruel. A monster.  And an innocent child.  If I could reach the boy.
This is Stargher we're talking about?

You think you can do this, don't you?

I did, yeah.
You thought Stargher wanted to be caught.
As soon as I met him, you knew I'd say yes.  He makes Julia real for me.
You're the shrink, you tell me.

A kingdom.  His utopia. Life without consequence or restriction. He's not even Carl Stargher anymore. He's this... idealized version of himself who can do anything he pleases... Without fear.  A horrible primitive ugly thing.  I don't want to talk in here.
What did you see?
With Stargher I saw things...
That's what therapists are for, right?
Just like we all have fantasies, right? Things only we know, that we don't share.

Do you feel there's a side of yourself you don't show people?
Peter, okay?
Agent Novak?
Ah, the part of us that can't be explained.
The soul.  The spirit.  Whatever you want to call it.
What then?
It doesn't have much to do with science.

I read about a woman in TExas who was in a coma for seven years.  Every time her husband came to visit, her heart would beat faster.  Isn't that something?  I don't know what name scientists have for something like that...
No.  Not at all.  From what I understand, he knows I"m here, isn't that right?
Do you think that's funny?
Edward Baines, I presume.  Hi, Ed.  I'm Pete.
I know him.
You don't know the procedure.
This man is deeply disturbed, he...

I realize that...
I still don't understand why I can't do this... This isn't some "troubled kid" you're dealing with.

Okay.  Let's assume he wanted you to find him, that some part of him hated what he was doing... Most likely, that part is dead.  Schizophrenics with Whalen's Infraction sever all ties with the real world.  I'm sorry, I really am.

Sometimes... Once they've been caught they feel a need for disclosure.  They have so much they want to tell. But they've never had a sympathetic ear. They need someone to understand why.  Stargher used to hide the bodies very carefully.  It was part of the ritual. Some weren't found for weeks and any physical evidence had been meticulously wiped clean.  But these last three... They were still in water - always in water - but  Listen, he wasn't just careless.  It went beyond that...

Really?  I don't work with violent cases, I work with children.  But even a kid lies.  They love it when they get you to believe something that isn't true.  Don't you think Stargher would do the same?
There's always a chance they'll confess.
As far as I needed.
What if he wasn't like this?  What if he was "normal?"  Conscious.  How far would you go?

Mocky-Lock.

's broken.

Pump in two liters of pure oxygen, please Henry.

Catherine has a tremendous capacity for empathy.  When we started, there were a number of test subjects - other therapists - who acted as "receivers."  All they did was observe and report.  Nothing more.  But Catherine, she had the ability to feel what was happening.  She understood. And the patient responded.  Edward engaged her in dialogue, took her places, showed her things.  He knew she cared.
Not a gift.  A highly evolved area in her cerebral cortex, that's all.  A genetic fluke.

Shouldn't we get a catheter in him?

When we got here, you just topped and pulled her out.
I'll get her...

Stargher is in custody.  The functional equivalent of being under arrest. Normally, we'd Mirandize him, and if he didn't lawyer up, we'd interrogate him. But because of his condition, he doesn't have the capacity to waive those rights.

I don't mean that. How would he act? What would he do?
To the eye? Like other men.
If there were a man like that, with a kink in his brain around here loose, what would he be like.
Yes. There have been men who kill for pleasure -- strange pleasure. There was Blue Beard in France -- Jack The Ripper in London. It's not uncommon.
All right -- the dead, then.  In history there must have been men like that -- men with kinks in their brains --
But all those fancy courses were about the dead, Jerry, not the living.
You know a lot. You've taken a lot of fancy courses in colleges and that kind of stuff - - what kind of a man would kill like that?
Just barely possible - - yes.
You must admit it's possible that it might have been a man.
Some other time.
Don't you want to see the rest of the exhibit?
Come on, Charlie. Let's go find another and better suspect.
You, Charlie -- you know leopards. You might have had an old claw around somewhere, and perhaps a bit of hair from the cage - eh?
I don't know.
Yes, but what sort of a man?
A hunch -- that's all I've got about this leopard thing. It's just a hunch, yet I feel it deep in the stomach. It was a man!
We had given up digging in a certain barrow. I went back and I tried again. I just had a hunch.
But he would have to know about leopards - have access to leopard claws and hair.
Some crazy guy.
I can understand what you mean - demented men, pathological cases. But what sort of man would kill like a leopard and leave the traces of a leopard?
There are all sorts of men. You get to see some funny ones as a reporter.
It could be. Why would a man kill her? For what? It wasn't robbery. It wasn't a crime of jealousy or passion. She had no enemies.
It could be a man.
Charlie likes his leopard.
Charlie doesn't think the leopard killed the girl in the cemetery.
Yes.
About Charlie's leopard?
Charlie and I were talking. That's one reason I wanted to see you.
I'll take you about. Got some nice things.
More or less.
Come to look around?
We're old friends.
You know Charlie How-Come?

I can understand about the cat killing the first girl. Charlie How Come told me. All that noise and those lights -- scared crazy it would do anything. Last night there was nothing to disturb it. Just a little girl alone in a cemetery.
Just a minute, Robles.  Let him go on.
Caged animals are unpredictable. They're like frustrated human beings. I can't answer your question.
But it doesn't eat what it kills.
It doesn't know how to hunt its natural prey.
Why?

Jerry, I talked to you about the habits of an ordinary wild leopard. This leopard is another matter entirely - - a caged animal travelling around with Charlie How Come for years and years.. That's why it kills human beings.
That's what I don't understand -- why should it come here -- and why didn't it stay here? It's got trees and bushes here -- outside nothing but cement and asphalt.
Sure -- certainly - but what's that got to do with this?
It doesn't jibe with this  you told me the leopard would go out into the country - it wouldn't stay in the city
Yes?
Doc -- something you said the other day --
Don't feel so concerned, Jerry.
That's right, of course.
There is no danger at all. It's a wild animal. Do you think a wild animal prefers walls, streets and people when it can get into open country?
No. I'm quite sure.
You know about animals -- their habits -- will it come back?
Of course. It's the way any decent man would feel in your position.
Yes. I want to go out and patrol the town - be everywhere at once - be sure nothing happens to anybody.
You're worrying about its killing someone else?
It's about the leopard.
I want to ask you something.
Well, I'd best be off.
Yes. It's always fascinated me.  You know, once, when I was a youngster, I went to see Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Zaza." After the play I stood in the alley just to watch her come out.
Show business?
No - really, I can see them -- they're coming now - turn off the lights
Wait
They do, but -- there are no lights out there - they'll just be shadows -
I thought they came right past here
Of course. Only I'm afraid you'll be cheated. There isn't much of a view of the procession here.
Miss Walker -- I didn't expect anyone
I've disturbed	you. I'm sorry -
Thanks.
I'm sure if you are as talented as you are charming, Miss Walker, you have nothing to worry about.
Well, I'm next. You won't hear anything like that, Mr. Galbraith.  I'm not a popular favorite since I let the leopard loose.
That was a calamity!
That was unfortunate.
Well, I'm hardly Mrs. Leslie Carter whoever she was. In fact, I'm not even much of a success around here particularly after the backfire on Jerry's little publicity stunt with the leopard.
So you see meeting you is a real thrill for me.
Various reasons.  But I can't see why you'd be interested in the rather dusty career of William Galbraith  teacher, naturalist, curator -- when you lead such a gay and exciting life yourself.
Why did you give up teaching?
There's a little museum here in town. They've hired me to run it, We've some interesting exhibits of Indian arts and crafts. It's fun -- and I like living here in New Mexico.
What do you do now?

To know where that leopard went -  I'm afraid you'd have to be a leopard and think like a leopard. I was a naturalist. That hardly qualifies me as an expert in hunting down lost leopards. I used to teach zoology in a little freshwater college back East. I gave that up.
Jerry told me you were an expert with animals, Mr. Galbraith. Couldn't you tell where it went?
Offend a reputable citizen and involve the department in a slander suit? No. I'm in office to protect the taxpayers money  not throw it way. Come on, Charlie.
You won't go to Galbraith with me?
Yes. And I am taking it to headquarters for examination.
That's a fact, isn't it?
I am not interested in what somebody else thinks. You being me facts and I'll act on them.
Galbraith knows something. He as good as said so
I'm sure of it!
You think Galbraith found the leopard on the day you went out with the posse.
Chief, don't you understand what this means?
Ask Kiki. Ask any woman. Girls don't put on lipstick in the middle of the night on a dark, lonely street unless they're with a man or expecting a man.
Why?
Yes. The lipstick.
Professional hunters, who rid the state of cougars.
State hunters?
No. He was kidding Charlie.
Let me get one thing clear. Did Galbraith make a direct accusation?
I've been trying to tell him, Sheriff. He won't listen to me.
Nothing much -- just that it might not be a cat this time.
What are you getting at?
I know all that, chief, and I don't like it any better than you do, but there's something else --
Yes, there is something wrong. People who want publicity and don't mind how they get it --what risks they make other people run - - what agony and sorrow they bring to other people --
Something's wrong with this whole setup --
That's why it just mauls and tears at them.
It's not for me.  I'm literally and figuratively a tenderfoot.
Go on foot.
I haven't done any posse work since last time I rode with Toni Mix at the old Bijou Theatre -- aged six, If you're interested,
Thanks, Sheriff.
You can go now, Manning. There is no way we can hold you legally responsible.

Kiki, Galbraith said something to me once, -- something you ought to know. We were talking and he said that people were like that ball on the fountain at the hotel --they got pushed around by things bigger than themselves. That's the way it was with us -- and we were too small to see it that way.
It's a lovely town - it was until we came and let the leopard loose and all this happened.
We ought to dare to tell each other everything, Kiki -- you and I.
Jerry, I want you to be soft. You are soft -- inside - where it matters. I wanted it that day too, but didn't dare tell you.
I know. What do you think I felt when you said, "don't be soft?"
I hated you that day - you and your flip talk - with that little girl lying dead.
I know -- Teresa -
We stood here once before.
It's all right. I'm not hurt.
Kiki?
We will
No. No, thanks.  Now we've got to do it ourselves.
How do you know?
Half to the Delgado family and half to Clo-Clo's family.
All right, I'm not ashamed of it! I split it two ways
Eloise doesn't own enough of anything to make a dent in your pay check, Kicks.
I -- I bought some silver jewelry and stuff from Eloise --
What! You can't be --
As a matter of fact, I'm out of cash myself.
That's funny -- I never knew you to lose that much before --
I got into a little crap game.
Didn't you take your cut out of the closing check?
Oh, by the way -- I'm out of cash --
I'm no detective. I don't even know how to begin. All I know is I want to do something about all this.
You already know the answer to that. I want this town to be safe and happy again --
Absolutely sure.
You're positive of that, aren't you?
Kiki -- it wasn't the leopard.
If that's being a softie -- there are two of us.
Confession. I'm a complete softie. I've been conscience-stricken and worried sick ever since that leopard got away --
Maybe there ought to be less racket and more us.
I'm glad you care about us, Kicks. Sometimes that gets kind of lost in the racket --
You. Us.
What else do you care about, Kicks?
That doesn't make sense.
Maybe I want to feel badly.
Why do you want to stay around here? It'll only make you feel badly.
Robles says it looks that way. Belmonte had already been there and left. They only missed each other by a few minutes.
And she waited here for him?
Yes. Do you mind?
You mean you want to take them to the cemetery.
Jerry, these flowers aren't really for me
Yes.
I know. Funerals.
Pretty. You know -- it's funny but flowers only mean one thing to me now.
He's a nice guy. Vie ought to keep in touch with him.
That was nice of Mr. Galbraith.
Do they close up every year for this Processionist business?
I can use them.
And not a sign of the leopard?
As long as my feet held out.
You remember the fellow this morning -- Galbraith. You've got time before the supper show.
Who is he?
Forget it. I'm buying a drink for a fellow who was on the posse with me, a nice guy. Come along he'll get a great kick out of meeting you.
Our first real break -- and we throw wild animals at the audience
The whole town's in a state, Kiki doors locked, people huddling together like scared sheep nobody on the streets at night
It must be the altitude  you, bucking around the countryside with a lot of bootandsaddle boys --
And did you find the leopard?
Yeah.
Well, does everybody love us now? You've been gone long enough to softsoap twenty editors!
We all, had to look at the body. It was awful, Kiki -- awful!
What did he have to do - look at the body?
I don't know  a witness. He seemed to know something about animals -- you know -- expert testimony.
Who was the other man?
And I suppose you don't feel bad!
I suppose he was trying to make me feel bad.
Don't be soft.
Suppose I slip them a few bucks  for the funeral expenses.
Now look what you've done.
Are you all right?
The red dress?  No. My black one. Then I'll be just like him.
You look swell in that threealarm number --
I thought you might strut this kitten in right in the middle of her act.
Clo-Clo?
And I never will -- you know what's between us - we're a thing -- But this is serious -- big competition.
No  not yet.
Almost three years, isn't it? And have I ever done anything to hurt you?
This is l939. Can't you subtract?
Look, Kicks, how long have we known each other?
You're too good to me.
No. I thought that might be just a little corny.  I want you to lead him in on a leash.
On his back, I suppose.

I thought - is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance  this town will never forget.
That's easy. Me.
Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this time.
Makes no difference.  Get him out.
Kiki - he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.
Get it out of here!
And I never will- you know what's between us  we're a thing But this is serious competition.
No - not yet.
Look, Kicks, have I ever done anything to hurt you?
You're too good to me.
No. I thought that might be just a little corny. I want you to lead him in on a leash.
On his back, I suppose.

I thought -- is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance this town will never forget!
That's easy. Me.
Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this tine...
Makes no difference. Get him out!
Kiki -- he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.
Get it out of here!
You a tourist?
Ha-ha... Yeah...  What about that road back there, though? It says closed to the public, doesnt it?
Maybe for the same reason that made someone somewhere not consider this a spot to build the Getty Museum...
Nobody? Huh!... How come?
Aint nobody out there, Mister.
All those soldiers out there... getting bored, thirsty. Come out here for refreshment or female company perhaps?
Must it?
Hot...  These roads all round here, closed to the public... Whys that? Military bases?  Huh. I guess theres space enough for war games... Must be good for business.
Dial O-O-O on the telephone if you change your mind about the drink, sir.
Mrs De Moraes must have taken it hard, eh?  Her brothers death.
No. Thank you. Ill be fine...
You will have to ask Mr De Moraes that, sir.  Would you like a drink while you wait?
You wouldnt recall if the brothers-in-law left together, would you?
I work here, sir. Im here most of the time.
By the way, Laurence, were you here last time your mistresss brother came over? You know, just before he disappeared?
Mr De Moraes is due back from Brazil late this evening. Mrs De Moraes is out and not expected before eight. Do you wish...
When will they be back?
Im afraid they are out at the moment, sir.
Could I speak to Carlos or Deborah?
Good afternoon. De Moraess residence.
That would be Mrs De Moraes mother, Sir. Mr and Mrs Spitz are here with their daughter.
De Moraes? I was asked here by a Mrs Spitz.
I am Lawrence, sir. Mr and Mrs De Moraes majordomo. They are expecting you.
That might depend on where youre going.
Will you please come with me?
Thats right.
The dead can wait.
I... We have to bury Leon tommorrow...
You wouldnt understand.
Why the hell couldnt you divorce the man?
Your parents arranged the visit to my office?
I dont know. Everyones dead...
What do you suggest?
On... Once...  Once... What are we... you going to do?
So you did talk about it, huh?
My parents flew back from Israel... Told him they would get him killed unless he flew back to Brazil immediately and agreed to a divorce. He flew back to Brazil...  And his drowning was arranged...
Get to the point, will you...
The staff dont know yet...  I called my parents, told them everything...  I just couldnt take any more...
Your flunkey said he was expected back tonight.
They found his body yesterday. In the pool at our house in Sao Paulo. He drowned. Drank too much, went for a swim and drowned.
No. Not us...
We? You and your parents killed your husband?
