Do you think wed let him get away with the murder of my brother?
He... He is dead!  MY HUSBAND IS DEAD!  Call my parents. Theyll tell you. Call them!
Do you think the boy you saved might identify your husband as his purchaser, Deborah? And then, your brothers not buried yet. As I said earlier, an autopsy will...
What are you doing? You cant. I...

You know something? Ive just seen so much ugliness I dont think Id mind four walls and dinner served every night at a regular time.  Id hoped to have a private word with Adonis, but if thats the way you want it.

Perhaps I did... Until fear turned into panic. Thats when he hit me, and told me hed killed my brother... You dont know what youve done, he said.  Were in deep trouble, he said. We, he said. We.  Wed both be killed if Friedman ever found out you were working for us, he said. We had to stop you and Friedman meeting...
Well, I hope you enjoyed yourself.

I didnt intend it that way... It just happened.  He heard from Laurence that youd been back.  That wed argued. He asked why and it just happened; I told him everything... I couldnt help it. Wanted to see him scared. I had never seen him scared before, you see...
To get me killed...?
My husband didnt need to slap me about, Mr Lombard. I volunteered...
Perhaps it came to me while dying in a Californian desert because a woman set upon giving her husband a fright got slapped about a little.
You seem to know what youre talking about.
We all have to like what we become. Cowards included. We achieve this by complicating things a little. But its never that complicated really.
Should I?
Dont you believe in simplicity?
Simplify and damn.
Where is that?
Here we go again.
What happened? Adonis slapped you about a little and you reverted to cowardice?
Something like that.
Something like that?
Something like that.
What was the idea? Husband is filled with fear when he learns his child suppliers being tailed?
I didnt know who or what had happened to my brother yet, Mr Lombard!
A fright?... Five years of cowardice led to your brother being murdered and you wanted to give his murderer a fright?
Maybe I wanted to give my husband a fright.
And you still havent told me why you sent me after Friedman.
...Were turning in circles.
Are there truly no extenuating circumstances?
You splendid bastard...
Five years of it. Surely, youd have divorced him if he disgusted you?
You bastard...
Rich. Young. Beautiful. You must at least get a kick out of what he does to his kids.
Why do I feel I neednt answer that?
Is there anything to understand?
Good.
I dont.
Think what you like. But dont presume to understand.
One just doesnt... Tell me, what does one speak about, huh?

I didnt know my husband and Friedman knew each other. I just...  Do you think we spoke about it? Ive known for five years. Hes known Ive known for five years... But not once have we spoken about it. There are things one just doesnt speak about...
Why did you send me after Friedman? To atone for your sins?
That my brother, my husband and your Mr Friedman were linked, that much I had guessed. But that my husband had killed Leon? No.
You dont say.

Youre wrong about my being there, though. Carlos borrowed my car that day, his had broken down...  Leon saw it, like you, assumed I was there, thought hed wait to ask for a lift. But Carlos turned up, with the tape you found...  Leon got his lift, and accidentally picked up the tape with his photo equipment when he got out. He watched it, confronted Carlos, threatened to tell the police about the hotel... I dont know how he knew about the hotel. Perhaps Carlos talked too much... My husband did not tell me... You more or less guessed the rest...  I didnt know any of this before you left for Los Angeles.
Oh no. At long last Leon had found a mission. Hed never have killed himself when glory beckoned. Your husband killed your brother. And thanks to you, almost got me killed too.
Leon could still have hung himself.

Kids are not your thing, Deborah. Youd have been ready for me when I turned up with Sleeping Beauty. Damn it! Then too I should have paid more attention. Not Leon, you said. It struck me at the time, but obviously not hard enough. You didnt say My God!, or whatever else well-bred ladies squeak on hearing Uncle Henry misbehaved. Not Leon. Who then?  You sure were right about one thing, Deborah, the job was too formidable for me. I should have thought a little more before I left for Los Angeles. But there I was focused so hard on Friedman Id stopped thinking. Nothing added up - Leon soliciting money for prints while buying kids at 15,000 a go; infiltrating the world of child traffickers; duping Friedman into selling him a little boy... You sure were right. The job was too formidable for me. But you knew that, didnt you?
If-if my car is there, I could be the one who... Why dont you accuse me of killing my brother?

Your brother stumbled upon Adoniss little secret, didnt he? And traded his silence for a kid and some cash. And Adonis fell for it, bought him his kid, sent him away, and then killed him when he came back for more.  Leon didnt come here to borrow money for prints. He came to extort a second kids life. Your flunkey let him in, so his visit couldnt be concealed, hence the exhibition story. There was no exhibition. Just as you suspected. Remember, Deborah? Leon does his own prints. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art.  I should have paid more attention to your words. Perhaps its the way you say them...
Not in the strict sense of the word, no. He was in too much of a hurry to kill me when we first met and too wasted in acid when I caught up with him later.
...You-you spoke to him?

I doubt Friedman ever even met Leon, Deborah. Friedman dealt with select customers. As for my envelope, had he know where it was he wouldnt have mistaken me for a hitman called Lamont when we met in Los Angeles.
Leon didnt hang himself, Deborah. Your husband killed him and made his death look like suicide. How did he do it, eh? Strangulation? Drugs? No doubt an autopsy will tell.
Leon hung himself...

Leons not found, your parents worry, talk of hiring help to find him, even mention their manhunter friends perhaps... and Adonis panics, takes control, brings me in reckoning a small- time detective is unlikely to dig up anything awkward, not before Leons found anyhow. He must have kicked himself when he learned Id exceeded his expectations.
Leon hung himself...

Adonis thought your brothers bodyd be found reasonably quickly when he hung it in Epping Forest, didnt he? Seemed like a good idea. An ex-junkie, obsessed with death; the perfect candidate for suicide. He just forgot one thing: forest ramblers are rare during your average blustery English November. An Englishman might have thought of that, but a Brazilian...
Leon hung himself.
Does the name Pierre Dreyer mean anything to you? Hes a client of mine and a friend of your husband.
My brother hung himself.
What do you mean, No, Mrs De Moraes?
No!
Tell me, did he kill his little victims too?

It must be tough being married to Adonis to end up sleeping alone every night. Sleep must be hard coming. Whats harder? The thought of the fine litter you two could have bred if? Or imagining what he does with his children?
How... When did you...
I take it you learnt to live with yours then. Take it all the mind-dulling pills in your medicine cabinet are surplus to your well-being...
Huh! Dont you recall convincing me he had?  You should learn to live with your mistakes, Mr Lombard. There is some merit in it.
You knew he had nothing to do with your brothers disappearance, didnt you?
Whatever the reason, Im sorry I did. Goodbye, Mr Lombard. I believe you know your way out.
I guess the news youd sent me after Friedman didnt go down too well, eh?

You do have a vivid imagination, Mr Lombard. I only wish youd use it fruitfully instead of in being obnoxious. I fail to understand your purpose in this. Still, say what youre owed if you still wish to be paid or get out, all right?

When did you learn about his taste for kids, huh? On your honeymoon? Or was it later, when bitterness set in and you turned against your beloved but weak little brother? How did you find out? Did he confess? Try to convert you perhaps? Or was it womans intuition? Or just the way he fucked you?
Have you finished?

You know hed have had him killed, dont you? Does a conscience still burn somewhere inside your sore mind, Deborah? Or is it just cold expediency? Could the boy perhaps come in useful when and if the day ever comes for you to face up to the man you married?
Why... I dont know what youre talking about.

Ive had a long and unpleasant day. Im tired and Im angry. But mad? Not yet.  I paid Leons boy a visit this morning. Found him alive and well. Why havent you told your husband where he is since reading my note, eh?
Youre mad...

How did you break into my office, Deborah? Ladies of your standing dont learn to pick locks between shopping trips.  Come on, Deborah! Acting dumb doesnt suit you! Who knew Id found dirt on your brother, huh? Who knew it was in an envelope? Taking me for dead, whod want to make sure it didnt fall into the wrong hands?
You what, Mrs De Moraes? YOU WHAT?
You... You are out of order, Mr Lombard. I...
Or is it the other way round? The children are needed because you cant satisfy him?

Whats in the bag? Underwear? To seduce your husband? Or is it for your own recreation?  Tell me, how come such a handsome couple sleep in seperate bedrooms? Is it because he does it with little children?
Sorry?
Black suits you.

I... If you dont mind, I do not think he matters now. It... Things turned out to be as we thought; Leon was weak. Theres no point in delving into his sad life anymore. Now, will you please tell me how much we owe you?
Arent you curious to know about Friedman?
I... Well, were burying Leon tomorrow and... Look, I wish I had more time, but its late and with the funeral...
Youre repeating yourself, Mrs De Moraes.
Im really sorry you were not called...
Why dont you ask when I left the Mondrian?
When did you get back?
How are you, Mrs De Moraes?
Mr Lombard...
Uh... Wait a moment, Mrs De Moraes...
Mr Lombard. Mrs De Moraes...
Yeah. Goodnight, Mrs De Moraes.
Paul Lamont...?

Not yet. The place I hoped to find him turns out to be little more than a contact address. Ill give it 24 hours. He just might show up.  If you need to reach me ask for Mr Lamont. Paul Lamont, all right?
Yes... You woke me up... Its the middle of the night here. Have you found Mr Friedman?
Are you all right?
...7548. Have you... Have you found him yet?
The Mondrian, room 504. The number is 266 7548, plus the L.A. code...
Just a moment...  Go ahead.
Have you got a pen?
Mr Lombard?
You do want me to keep the job, dont you, Mrs De Moraes?
You drive a hard bargain, Mr Lombard.
W-why are you telling me all this, Mr Lombard?
Minimizes the risks. Children can be moved across borders using reliable businesses. These can also be used to move women and drugs... Anything that makes money really.
The hotels are useful capital investments. The kids liquid assets. My guess is they own hotels across the globe, and travel agencies specialising in flights from the third world to boot.
Huh! Really? Hotels?

You watched the tape?  Friedman and his people dont just provide little kids and videotapes, Mrs De Moraes. Theyre in the import-export business. They run hotels here in London which they probably use as ware- houses and ports of call for their merchandise.
Are we understood?

Well, I found a little more than that. Let me put it this way:...  Last night I thought your brother might be dead, tonight Im convinced he is. That said, I have no evidence and I advise you to let the police deal with it.
Im impressed. That information could have cost me 20,000.
The man who sold the boy to your brother.
Who is Friedman?
You could say that. And Friedman left this morning for Los Angeles.
You lost my money?
Last night you upset my sleep. Tonight my social life. We have two minutes. My dinner guests are waiting.
Thank you for coming. Come in and close the door, will you?
You drive a hard bargain.

I still dont buy your story but I figured it cant do any harm to let you go on with your enquiry. Besides, if you do turn out to be nothing but a cheap little extortioner, we could always get the right people onto you. I trust you know who I am talking about.
Couldnt Nazi hunters do the job?
Huh! Who do you think we are, Mr Lombard?
Why me, Mrs De Moraes? Why should such well-connected people as you hire a small- time French detective to look for their missing son, Mrs De Moraes?
The family hired you and I have just fired you, Mr Lombard.
I was hired by your parents, Mrs De Moraes.
Laurence!
No. Youre fired! Get out of my house. And take your sick tape with you...
Perhaps I should come back when youre...
Get out of my house. Youre fired, Mr Lombard.
Excuse me?
No. The question now is how long its going to take you to get out of here, Mr Lombard.
The question now is whether or not your brother still owns anything, Mrs De Moraes.
How dare you...  You dont know this tape belongs to my brother, do you, Mr Lombard?

Look, Mrs De Moraes, however much of a let down it might be, your brothers not back to his old weekend tricks! Impressionable as he is, he probably grew tired of healthy girls in grisly poses, tried moving on to bigger things, came upon more than hed bargained for and somehow fancied he could take on the real world. Which he no doubt chanced upon on his way to that thing now sitting on your table... Have a look at it, Mrs De Moraes. I told you I had bad news...
Oh no. Youll have to do better than that, Mr Lombard.
I cant tell you that yet. But hes being well looked after.
Where is it?  He. The boy you said my brother bought! Where is he?
I will of course do my best to hang onto it.
I need the money to smooth my way, you understand? Now, have you got that sort of cash here or do we need to meet in the morning?
Excuse me?

Your brother got mixed up with child procurers  and tried to make this world a better place, Mrs De Moraes. And having rescued one little life he unwisely set out to repeat the exercise.  You dont mess around with child procurers. Right now my guess is hes either on the run, held captive, or dead.  I understand your misgivings, Mrs De Moraes. But Ive seen the boy and made telephone contact with the man Leon bought him from. If anyone knows what happened to your brother it will be that man. Which leads me to why Im here at such a late hour. I need 20,000, in cash, by 11 this morning.
What... What are you talking about?

You seem surprised. Could it be you dont think that badly of him after all?  You neednt worry. It seems his motives were pure. From what I can make out he bought the boy to rescue him from further abuse.
Theres more. Your brother also purchased a young boy for 15,000.
You... You found that at Leons?
Its a snuff movie. Prime paedophile material. Im told it retails at around 4,000.  I see you dont require a definition.
Disney! How inter...
I found this at your brothers.
Anything is possible.
Can it be that you want your brother found?
Can it be that easy?
Now you are confusing me, Mrs De Moraes.

Oh-oh! Touch, Mr Lombard! But tell me, what would you know about sisterly love, eh?  No. Dont. You might get confused speaking of things you dont understand and we need you clear- headed, at least until youve done what we are paying you for.
I dont know. He seems to delight in so much sisterly love, he might become determined.
For your information, Mr Lombard, trouble is possibly the one thing Leon is capable of getting into all by himself. Though I doubt he will not ultimately fail even at that.
Im afraid I have bad news, Mr De Moraes. I have reason to believe your brothers in trouble.
I wont comment on the time but youll understand if I dont tell you to sit down. Now, spare me the apology and get to the point, will you, Mr Lombard.
Was it cash, Mr De Moraes?  The 1,000. You gave it to him in cash?
Perhaps it wasnt so brave of him. Had I been here I just might have given him his money, Mr Lombard. One can reap rewards from the strangest of conduct, as someone in your line of work ought to know.
Is that why your brother braved coming here to ask you for a loan?
I have too much money to work, Mr Lombard.
What about you, Mrs De Moraes?

Well, Leon does not need money for prints, Mr Lombard. Does his own printing. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art!  Which, as he subsequently vanished, raises the question: what was the money for? Perish the thought.
And that is the last time any...

Three weeks ago. To borrow money. I wasnt here but he got to my husband, sold him some fancy story about an exhibition of his work and needing money to get new prints made. Carlos handed over 1,000 to get rid of him.
That depends what youre looking at.
Appearances can be deceptive, Mrs De Moraes.
Now you know why youre here, Mr Lombard.  It might be difficult for someone like you to discern, but we are people of a certain standing.
Can you tell me how you spell...
Penrhyndeudraeth, North Wales.
A call box? Thats odd. Where exactly?
Theres nothing wrong with the line, sir. Are you sure you have the right number? 770 471 is the number of a call box.
01766 770 471. Let me check it for you, sir.
Yes. Im trying to reach a friend but I cant get through. The number is 01766 770 471.
Directory enquiries. Can I help you?
Not in America, sir. You must be from Europe.  So, black coffee and a couple of crescents.
The word for those things is croissants.
Croissants. Like that...
Im sorry, sir. Could you try that again?
Croissants.
Crow what?
A coffee and a couple of croissants.
Good morning, sir. How can I help you?
Huh! And they say charitys only rewarded in Heaven... Hallelujah...  Christ...
Nothing sticks to slime, Emily.  This should cover what you lent me.
I can... The question is, can you lie to your ex- husband?
You cannot walk away from this. You cannot.
Theyd never let me go. And youd end up in more trouble than you know for helping me.

My ex-husband. My work drove him away. Made his life a misery. He thinks Im obsessed, punishing myself for what happened to our son.  But hes a good guy. Hell listen to you. He wont turn you in if I ask him not to. I can pretty much guarantee that. Okay?
What about your friendly cop?

...Im Emily Stewart. The hysterical female who sees evil everywhere since the day her thirteen year-old boy disappeared. The pain in the ass who cries wolf at the drop of a hat. However I go about this thats who I am. Do you get what Im fucking saying, Mr Lombard?
Its up to you whether they walk or not.
Damn it! You cant fucking walk away from this!

Look! Either you talk or the creeps are gonna walk. For gods sake. What am I supposed to say? I got this from a French guy from England who broke in there to have a chat with an Austrian child trafficker? Is that it?
Then find another way.

A seminar in a baby breeding farm! Bodies in acid! You think Ill get anywhere with that? Jesus! With luck I might raise a laugh. They might even send a patrol car to check the place out. Whatever, itll be too late.
Im finished here and Im tired, Emily. You shouldnt be here. Now dont make it worse.
That-that wont do. Thats not the way it goes. You saw it, you tell it, thats the way...
Call from the motel and tell him if he moves fast enough there might be something left of a body dissolving in acid.  Can I have the keys to your house?
Do you know a friendly cop?
Were both thinking the same thing, right?

No one saw me but the Italian and a dog. I blew up their generator. They thought it was an accident but by now they must have realised one of their party is missing. It might make them feel insecure enough to decide to pack up...
Who knows. Who cares...  You wanted slime. You got slime.
Italian? The Mafia...?
Some Italian I picked up back there. Hes in the boot of the Mustang.
So who... Whos the man? Where is he?
Friedmans dead... They killed him...
What...  Some kind of organ factory... Pregnant girls doped up. Babies. Theres a lot of people back there. Theyre holding a seminar. Traffickings the past, breeding the future...
What...?
Whos the guy? Whos the guy! Nom de Dieu!  Had the guy got a closer look at you or your number plate Id have had to kill him.
Look, you dont tell me about some Godforsaken place where stuff so bad even I couldnt imagine it goes down and expect me to go quietly to sleep! What happened? Whos the guy? The Austrian?
I think so. And if it comes to it, tell the cops anything you think will make them move. Whatever you came up with couldnt come close to how bad it is. Bye now.
Have you found your man? Is that where he is?

Route 395. Past Edwards Air Force base and about half a mile before a place called the Red Mountain Motel. Theres a dirt track with a Closed to the public sign. It leads to some kind of ranch in the middle of nowhere. If you havent heard from me by morning send the cavalry, okay? But not before, you hear?
Oh. What... Yeah. Okay.
Get a pen and dont ask any questions.
Burn the passport and keep the money. Think of it as a donation to the cause...
What am I to do with the packages if...
Dont fall asleep with your hair wet.
Yeah. Goodnight, Emily.
Right... Well, Ill get your money first thing in the morning, okay?  Okay. Goodnight then.
Thank you. But I think Ill go to bed. Its been a long day.
A little too tight, eh?  ...They were my sons. Only thirteen and already six feet tall. A real lanky boy...  I... Theres some cold chicken salad in the fridge if youre hungry.
Come on, Mr Lombard. You tailed your man all the way here from Europe. You told me you knew where to find him, remember? Or didnt I hear you right?
Huh... I have no... ... hard evidence...
Did you not enter this country illegally?
A criminal?
Its give and take time, Mr Lombard. You need help, we need information. You didnt really expect me to put my ass on the line helping a criminal just for the thrill of it, did you?
Did you call me up here to enjoy yourself, Emily, or to let me use your phone? Because we seem to have a slight problem...

How come youre alive? Child traffickers usually achieve what they set out to do.  What am I really looking at here, huh?  Are you really not just a lousy private eye? Am I really looking at some kind of cunning dispenser of justice in disguise?
Thank you for the guided tour, but would you mind telling me what were doing here?
Like youll find a way to stop your Austrian killing you a second time round?
Im sure Ill find a way.
No answer. You have no passport and your Embassys out. How do you plan to leave the U.S., Mr Lombard?
Hah... What about Nathalie?

A recent acquisition. Weve had four break- ins this year alone; files stolen, computers wrecked, faeces smeared on walls. The good guys dismiss us as alarmist do-gooders; the bad guys will risk prison to intimidate and rob us. An easy living indeed, Mr Lombard.  I got through to Moreau and Jane. I left your landlord out of it. Your flats been broken into. Jane wants you to call her back.
I wouldnt mind. Thank you.

Thereve been 7 international treaties since 1904 aimed at preventing child slavery. But still no worldwide body dedicated to investigating the maltreatment of children used in sexual exploitation. Officially, its just not called for. Sit down. Can I offer you some coffee?
I might come back, I might not. But if I do, it wont be for a couple of hours.
I know where to look.
You know where to look for your Austrian, right?

I thought youd never ask... As I was having my coffee and crescents at the Mondrian the other morning I spotted your photograph in the Los Angeles Times... Theres a tough lady, I thought. Just the kind who might help me...
There are over 4 million people in this city - why me?
Lombard...  It will take a few days for the things I need to get here. Meanwhile Id sooner not draw police attention walking the streets like a hungry dog...
Have you never heard of collect calls, Mr...
No. A poor little rich boy who thought hed save a few kids from their retailer. He disappeared on his second shopping expedition.
You dont know why hes come to Los Angeles?  The man you say he killed? Who was he? A colleague of his?
Yeah.
By your Austrian?
The Mondrian, room 504. I was checked out in my absence.
Where were you staying before the attempt on your life and why cant you go back there?
French people need a visa to enter this country. That takes time and I didnt have any. I used a British passport. My names not Lamont but Lombard. Xavier Lombard.
Okay. The woman just cant walk away...  I want straight answers. No hesitation or I walk for sure. Why cant you go to your Embassy?
You...  Jesus Christ!
Well, Id sooner mug an old lady...
I cant believe this...  Whats coming now, eh? If I dont pay all Hells gonna break loose, is that it?
A small loan would be welcome. More urgently, I need access to a telephone and an address where things can be sent to me.
Is this some kind of sick stunt? Let me guess.  You want money, right?
Im fine standing, thank you.
Youre sure you wont sit down, Miss Stewart?
I dont smoke. If you could get to the point...
You wouldnt have a cigarette, would you?
Youre a long way from home...
Europe...  France. Im French but I live in London...  ... England.
May I ask where youre from, Mr Lamont?
Shell be alright. Shes tough...
Shit! Fuck! Whats fucking wrong with people!  Im going to bed. And sweet dreams to you to!

No. Youre looking at a real Musketeer here, Whitney. Brave and rash. Had to dash in there.  Take a prisoner... Might as well have sent them a notice to quit...  Come on, Musketeer! Got anything to say?
Emily...
Look at him, Whitney. Come all the way from England to clean up California. Huh!
Thats right. Wheres the fucking Italian, eh, Mr French hero?
Weve still got the Italian...

Most of our information comes out of the mouths of babes, Mr Lombard - confused and frightened victims. Its all too easily discredited, you understand. Now, you might be just what weve been waiting for. Your information could be enough to make em sit up and listen.
If you have hard evidence about a child trafficker, we want it, Mr Lombard. And we want it before you get yourself killed...
Hi...
And losing you, wed lose him. And that would be a shame, dont you agree?
Whitney Armstrong, my deputy. What Whitneys trying to say is that you might not live to tell the tale next time you meet your Austrian...
Have the money ready by 11am. Well call you.
... Fine. Ill go for the safe place.
Fifteen for a straight delivery. Twenty with the provision of a safe place. Visitors tend to find the second option more convenient.
I see. How much?
Im afraid the only pups currently available at such notice are brown and trained. But they are all very cheerful and have been thoroughly checked for diseases...
Tomorrow?
How much of a hurry are you in?
What about an untrained pup, white...
So, what are you looking for?
Yes... Good, good...
We also provide 24-hour after-sale service. Were the puppy to fall sick or accidently die, we would unburden you, you understand?
Yeah.
Pups. Bitches. From three to twelve months.  Trained and untrained ones. White and brown ones. You understand?
What sort have you got?
What sort of puppy are you looking for?
This is a bad line.
Why?
May I have your phone number?
I saw the ad at Georges.  Im passing through town and Im in a hurry.
Have we done business before?
Im calling about the puppies.
Downstairs... At the front... Jesus...
Where is it?
B-Black...
What colour is your car?  What colour is your car?
F-five. The Wilsons and their three kids. They run the place. Look, man, Ive got to get to...
What about the staff?  Theyre in on whats going on, arent they?  How many of them?
Another hotel. Down the road. Martin lives there. He took your money. Hes got a safe...  I need a doctor...
Whats the Ambassador?
Just me...  Martins gone back to the Ambassador. Look...
How many of you scumbags are here?
I dont know. I dont know, man. I dont even know Friedman that well... I...  Man, youve got to get me out of here...
What company?
The company. We all work for the company.
And who does Friedman work for?
I dont know...  This is just a delivery place, man! I swear I dont know where the kids are... I work for Martin, thats all. Martin knows. He works for Friedman. He knows...
There were six on offer, you scumbag. Where are the other five?
What kids?
Where are the kids?
Finsbury Park. Were in Finsbury Park.
Where are we?
What?
Where?
Yeah... The Diplomat.
Whats this place? A hotel of some kind?
No... No...  I swear...
Ever seen him before?
Who?  Martin... Hes Martin...
Whos the money man?
Yeah... This morning. He left this fucking bloody morning... Jesus, man, my knees...
...On holiday?
I dont know. Hes gone!  Hes gone. I dont fucking know where, I swear... Hes gone. On holiday...
Where is he?
Yes. Friedmans the fuckin Austrian!
Where is the Austrian? Is Friedman the Austrian?
Who are you?
Jee... Fuck... Youre fucking mad!
Youre not playing with little boys now, scumbag. Where is the Austrian?
You... Fuck you!
Where is the Austrian?
What...?
On the bed!
I certainly did, sir...
You sure you passed on my message?
Got it. Puppies.
Next time he calls tell Mr Gluck he better be there to take his calls at 9 tonight or at 9 in the morning if he cares about his puppies. Got that?
Absolutely, sir. As a matter of fact he called this morning, sir.
Does Mr Gluck call for his messages?
Can I have the reception desk, please.
The Hyatt. Good afternoon. May I help you?
Ill call again.
Im sorry but Mr Gluck is not answering, sir.  Would you like to leave a message?
Thank you, Jane.
Yes. How did...
Carlos De Moraes?
Really? And how are you, eh?  Someone called Pierre Dreyer said that a month ago he had dinner with a Brazilian friend of...
Hello, Jane. Its me.
What are you up to, eh, Savieer? I mean, not this but... Money, passports, a gun in a microwave? Who are you, eh? Who are you?
Id appreciate it if you could do this for me. If you cant, dont worry about it. Ill call in about an hour anyway. Sorry but Im in a hurry.
Your secretary, huh!
Just ask if they can recall recommending my services to anyone in the recent past. Say youre my secretary, all right?
Thanks for cleaning my flat and sending my money, all right?... Come on, I need you. Its important.
Piss off!
Well, Im sorry. I...  This is my nephew... And my brother, Tim. Ive got the week off and hes come to stay.
Its not.
No... I told you on the phone. Whoever broke in messed-up all your papers. I put everything back where I thought it ought to be.  Maybe its there with...
Jane, there was an envelope in my desk. The one Id given you and then got back, remember? I cant find it. Do you know where it is?
Hello there. Hows the flat. I cleaned...
Oui, bonjour, Jean... Oui, trs bien, merci. Dites-moi, pourriez-vous me dire si vous avez recommandmes services quelquun rcemment... Vous tes certain... Non, non...  Je vous remercie...
I came to feed your fish. I didnt know...
Bye bye, Jane. And dont be naughty.
Shes pretty... See you, huh?

Oh yeah! Better be good and hurry away then! Who knows? We might be being watched! Maybe one of your stupid French companies has got a detective prying into your life - after all, thats what they do to their employees, isnt it? Huh! Hope you enjoy ruining peoples lives. Thanks for the lift!
Ive got work tonight, Jane.
Oh no. Im all right. He was a jerk, really. Another boy, you know? All I meet is boys. When I think of all the fuss about older men fancying young girls. I mean, is it true?
Well, I hope youre not too heartbroken and...
Oh... We split up.
Its Friday night, Jane. What happened to your latest boyfriend?
So you havent seen the film, then?
That are called Rommel or something, I guess not that many.
I dont know. How many famous French film directors can there be?
Should I?

La collectionoose. Its about a young girl in the south of France who seduces a different man every night and then meets one who resists her. Its on TV tonight and as Im in I thought we could perhaps look at your accounts and... The review says its about the conflict between intellect and instinct. And witty. The directors supposed to be famous. Rommel or something. French. You must know him?
La what?
Have you heard of a French film called La Collectionoose?

Yes. But my boss reckons youd still be better off as a limited company. For expenses and all that, you know? Itd cost you about 100 but he said itd be worth it.  Of course, youd need a partner to register. But thats a formality. I mean, I could be your partner. I mean, just as a name, right?
Good.
Must be your lucky day then. Ive got your accounts - you dont owe much tax for last year.
No.
Fine. How was the match? Did you loose?
How are you, Jane?
Hello again, neighbour. I didnt intrude, did I?
Jah...
Look at it this way. He might achieve everything your son never did.
Plus a trust fund to provide for the boys education.
10,000 a year to the girl for as long as she looks after the boy?
Fine. One more thing, Mrs and Mr Spitz; may I ask what is or was your occupation?
My husband and I will be leaving tomorrow for a short stay in Israel. Deborah will be here if you need anything before our return.
Ha... No, Mr Lombard. His monthly allowance is all he is to expect from us. He knows it and we feel the amount is more than adequate.
Why do you think your son chose not to come to you for funds for his photography, Mrs Spitz?
We are aware of your rates, Mr Lombard. We will pay you double your rates plus expenses. In return, need I say it again, we expect discretion and undivided attention.
My rates...
The 1,000 is on account.
When... Im told he came here...
Im sure... As far as you know, when and where was your son last seen?
The proprietor of his workplace is the only friend of his we know about.  His address is in this envelope with Leonards address, keys and other things you might need.
Any friends?
No. And before you ask, no, hes not gay! He has had girlfriends, but nothing serious...
I take it your son is not married, Mrs Spitz?
Then why arent you asking the police to look for your son, Mrs Spitz?
He could indeed, Mr Lombard. But had he done so I think he would have let us know about it.
So he could have decided to go on a trip...
Leonard does not hold a driving licence. As for his passport, I do not know where he keeps it.
Did you look for his passport, driving licence?
Yesterday. It all looked normal.
I presume you checked your sons apartment...
Then you should not have sought an explanation.
I didnt mean to imply you did, Mrs Spitz.

I said earlier that my husband and I are supporting Leonard in his photography, Mr Lombard. By this I mean that since his return from America I have been depositing for him a monthly allowance in an account we jointly hold. So as you see, I did not have to break the law to find out if he used the account.
Check with your sons bank. Banks dont usually give out information about their customers.
Do what, Mr Lombard?
How did you do that, Mrs Spitz?

You wouldnt be here if I knew, Mr Lombard. What I do know is that he has not been at work for three weeks. That enquiries to the police and London hospitals have borne no results. And that a check with his bank revealed he has not used his account for four weeks now.
What do you think has happened to your son, Mrs Spitz?
Leonard. What my daughter is on about, Mr Lombard, is that Leonard is somewhat of a Bohemian. You might as well know that...
I take it your son is called Leon?
What I can appreciate is insolence, Mr Lombard!

Look Mrs Spitz... I dont know to whom Im indebted for the recommendation but... Im not in the business of making oaths of allegiance or giving myself character references. What I do is listen to what the people who care to call me have to say and judge whether or not I can be of help. I hope you can appreciate that, Mrs Spitz.

Good. Now, as I trust you may have guessed, we are looking for someone to work for us. Someone whose discretion can be relied upon. Someone who while in our employ would give us full commitment. Do you think you could be that person, Mr Lombard?
Okay. Recommended...
You may not. And besides, it is irrelevant.
Didnt you say I came recommended?  Thats what I thought. May I know by whom?
Must I speak to you in French?
Recommended?
Whatever, you come recommended. We...
Well, I would have to point out that we could have dealt with that question when you called this morning, Mrs Spitz. I wouldnt like to think Id kept you waiting for nothing.
What if it is?
I hope its not too significant.
Lombard, this is not a Jewish name, is it?
May I ask if you are Jewish, Mr Lombard?
May I...?
Spitz. We spoke on the telephone.  My husband...  My daughter, Deborah, whose house this is.  My son-in-law, Carlos...  The gentleman is a business partner of his.
Good afternoon, Mrs...?
Ho-hotel... Los Angeles... He...
The Hyatt...? Whats that?
Hyatt... Friedmans... at the Hyatt...
Trying to say something, Martin?
Dying without ever reaching the top...
What is?
I told you... The rabble, its me...  Huh... Its sad.
You seem very sure about that.
Youre making a mistake, tough guy. Whoever he is, your guys not one of Friedmans...
Is this Friedman, Martin?  Come on, scumbag. Youve reached your sell- by date. Tell me if this is Friedman, where he is in Los Angeles and what name hes using?
Who are you? Who are you working for, huh?
Is this Friedman?
Could someone have hurt you that bad?
Huh... Im sure thered be lots of takers.
You know what, Martin? I ought to tie you down with your old arse up in the air and advertise the hole in the middle of it to the world. Free. And hope you never die.

Boys like the one you met today are surplus. Commodities worth a handful of notes in whatever arsehole of the world they happen to be born into. We improve some lives buying them where theyre not wanted, improve still more selling them where they are. Is that too hard for you?
Im overcome by your public-spiritedness.

Maybe you should. Think about it. Those who can afford our goods do their thing without upsetting anyone. Those who cant do it to kids from the streets or their own family and it makes upsetting headlines.
Maybe I dont.
Money talks, bullshit walks, whether you like it or not.
Only feeding the disease, eh, Martin?
Huh. Id have thought a tough guy like you would know better. The sick ones are out there, friend. They make up the clientle. Get rid of them and were out of business.
Is it real?  You people are sick.
Maybe the thought of people like you going on holiday bothers me. Come on, lets go...
Youre out of your mind. Whats the idea?
Shut up and drive!
This car needs petrol.
Dont jump any red lights.
No. In Hampstead... Why?
Friedman lives with you at the Ambassador?

Look, I dont think youre fully aware of what youre playing with here, Mister. Whoever put you up to this either pays too well or misinformed you. Why dont you just tell me what it is you want so we can do business in a civilized manner, eh?
Where is Friedman?
Huh, I doubt it...  Friedman only deals directly with select customers. I handle the rabble...
This one came back and was never seen again. I understand Friedman looked after him.
Clients come and go.
Six weeks ago. He bought a boy of yours.
Am I supposed to know him?
Right now your big friend at the Diplomat is bleeding fast, Martin. He might still possibly survive if attended to soon. And he did cooperate.
I dont know what your problem is, but...
Lets go.
Uh-huh. You couldve waited for me inside.
Is my money in there?
Problems?
Does it matter?
Vous tes Franais?
Anything at all. I presume you wont want to take the boy with you when youre finished?  Theres a 500 fee for disposal. The boy is yours, you understand?
Anything at all?
The rooms yours for 24 hours. Its sound- proofed, stocked up with food, drink and other things you might find useful. You can do anything you like.
We conclude our transaction.
What happens now?
We need a double-room and as I understand youre here alone wed be much obliged if youd agree to move to a single room...
What are you talking about?
This is the hotel supervisor, Mr Lamont. Im terribly sorry to disturb you but theres been a mix-up with our bookings which you might be able to help us resolve.
What is it?
Le Mercury. Newman street. Ask for Peter.
Three oclock.
At what time will you be available?
Yeah.
Its about the puppy. You got the money?
You must agree to be blindfolded...  Just for the journey. It might appear unseemly - youre the paying customer - but ordinarily clients come with some kind of endorsement.
Ill be alone.
Will you be alone?  The merchandise. Is it just you or...

Questions can amount to revelations. Now, Id hate to think I was made to come here carrying a substantial amount of money in order to be subjected to a cross- examination. Mr Friedman led me to believe we had a deal. Do we?
An Austrian... Not much to go on, is it?
An Austrian.
And while visiting our fair city you...  An Austrian?
The ladys not a friend. Shes a whore.  Someone at a special screening I attended mentioned certain goods could be got from an Austrian here in London. And not just movies.
Your lady friend did.
I dont recollect mentioning a friend.
The person who put us in touch seems to think so.
Have you?
I gather weve done business with a friend of yours?
Should I come back in five minutes?
Five to three. Youre early.
Yes. You wouldnt know where I could reach him? We had to discuss an exhibition of his photographs at my Paris gallery, you see? I really need to see him before I leave.
Im sorry...
Oh. This is... Wed arranged to meet tonight and Im due to return to Paris tomorrow...
No. I meant he left as in no longer works here.
Left? When? I just come from his place and there was no one there. A neighbour of his...
Leon? No. Im afraid he left.
No. Thank you. Could you tell me if Leon Spitz is here, please?
Evening. Table for one?
Good. You neednt worry about the Austrian anymore. Hes dead. Ill be in touch.
Fine...
Hows the boy doing?
He showed me a book with a picture of a couple caught kissing in a street...

... No. In fact, Id seen him a couple of months earlier. He was quite depressed. His work wasnt getting anywhere. He said he was going to try something new, realism, London in the nineties - documentary stuff, you know...
You sure? What about before he turned up with the boy?
Did he mention anything about having an exhibition of his work?
Yes. Three thousand pounds. I still...
The money Leon left for the boy, was it cash?

He... Apparently the hostility was all hers. Leon didnt... It hurt him. They used to be close...  Their parents were in their forties when they were born, you see. And mostly away. They grew up in a Scottish mansion with old nannies and servants. He... Our world was so old and cold, we shone for one another, Leon used to say. His sister cut him off after she got married. He never understood why but thought it was because she had no children. Was bitter...
Did he ever refer to the hostility between them?
Er... Yes...
Ive been away.  Did Leon speak to you about his sister?
The nineteenth... How come you didnt know?
Whats the date?
Hed come prepared. He had something besides Shiva... Sleeping Beauty. The Disney film...  Well, it looked like the Disney film. It was something else. I couldnt watch...
No sick people in the country, huh?... Just tell me one thing, Rhian. Leons story about the boy? You just took his word for it?
Im sorry. Its just you dont look local...
And you better stop greeting strangers with a shotgun. If Leons Austrian was looking for you I reckon hed have found you before I did.
Oh, I... She just moved. Ive got her new... Its in my book in the kitchen. Wait... Thank you.
I cant think of a good reason for it - for now anyway. My number if anything happens. Whats your sisters number?
Yes...You-youre not going to take Shiva away?
Is she on the phone?
My sister... She lives in the next valley.
Who else knows about the boy?
Albert... Albert and Ethel. Why?
Do you know Leons parents names?

Theyre German Jews. Came here before the war. They both lost all their families in extermination camps, but they themselves never went near one. The idea that his family wealth was started with money he believes should have gone to camp survivors has been haunting Leon. Its not guilt, more of a curse...  And then theres something about his parents being involved with Nazi hunters... But I think thats just one of Leons dark delusions...
Im afraid I dont understand.

Yeah... But he didnt beat the demons...  A quarter of all the shoes sold in Europe are made by or retailed through his parents leather empire. All started from a small shop in the East End of London and war reparation money for holocaust victims.
His mother would be pleased to hear that.

Thats what he said. I tried to dissuade him... Told him I couldnt take on another child, that hed get into trouble... I mean, people who sell children... But he wasnt listening... I guess he finally found himself a crusade... His family think hes back on drugs, eh?  Huh... Leon did drugs. A lot of drugs. Went through his self-destruct phase, you know?  Things to come to terms with. Demons to fight... Some peoples minds are gloriously uncomplicated. Not Leons. He did beat the drug, though. He did.
Good reasons?
He just said he had good reasons.
Did Leon tell you why he didnt want the police involved, Rhian?
We didnt quite make it as lovers... Leon is a good man, though...
Shut up!
What are you going to do now? Call the police?  Take him away? I must warn you hes terrified of men, so...
You-youre wrong. I just called to ask if I could stay with him next time Im in London. Thats all.
Havent you? Then why the worried messages on his answering machine, Rhian? Id have sworn you expect him to be in trouble.
You thought wrong. I havent seen Leon for months.
Well, I obviously do. And I also know that Leons not here, Rhian. But I thought that you might know where I should look for him.
...Leons not here. How did you get here? Phil doesnt know where I live.
As you know from speaking to Phil, your friend Leon has disappeared, Rhian. His family have hired me to find him.
No! What do you want here? How do you know me?
Can I get up now?
Whats a French private investigator doing here?
Should I be?
A private investigator... Youre not Austrian?
Reach for it and throw it to me. And... My fingers on the trigger, you hear!
In my jacket. Left inside pocket.
Shut up! Wheres your wallet?
Is this some kind of mugging? Because...
Wheres your wallet? Have you got a wallet?
Its wet. Will this do?
How are you, Rhian?
This is private property. The public footpath is back to the left of the bridge.

Is that where lawyers toil for an industry that turns serial killers into heroes who give thrills to young women who write erotic novels about psychopaths and rapists?  You go to your world, Ill stay in mine. So long, Mister.
Huh... I suppose the idea of a one day trip to Los Angeles doesnt appeal to you...
Barstows 30 miles to the left. Los Angeles a hundred to the right. Wherever youre heading, I reckon somebodyll pick you up.

Im sure you would. But if I had one, I wouldnt let you near it. Now you tuck back in and rest until youre told otherwise.  And for what its worth, I wouldnt try anything that might be construed as unappreciative of my hospitality. Id sooner shoot you than have you upset me...
Id appreciate it if I could use your phone.
Los Angeles is 100 miles away.
Los Angeles?
Huh... I guess you aint quite ready for civilisation yet... Ill give you one more day, a meal, and then youre on your way.
Three days and thats three days too many.Come on. Get your ass up.
I... How long have I been here?
Now, can you stand up?  Can you use your legs and stand up?

I didnt think so. The rags on their sorry backs are the only wordly possessions those wretched creatures are ever found with...  I dont wanna know who you are or how come you ended up roasting in Owl Canyon. But you might as well know Id have let you fry to a buzzard meal if not for this...
No...
And you aint neither one of those damned Mexicans who end up littering the landscape after getting ripped-off by their friendly cross- border guides, are you, mister?
Fucked-up fucking weird.
Yeah. Why? Youre going to look for her... Shit! You really think his pictures are that good?
Could that be Camden Market?
Yeah! Somewhere in Wales. I dont really know her. Used to turn up in a Transit van on weekends, sell old furniture at Camden. Thats how come he only laid her at weekends, ha ha...
Would you know where I might reach her?
Oh. Thatd be Rhian, a Welsh chick he used to lay at weekends. She got wise and dumped him months ago...
Small, blond, good-looking. She was with him when we met. She had a funny English accent.
What about which girlfriend?
What about his girlfriend?

Let me put it this way then; the photographs and the man? One and the same, man, one and the same. At best fucking weird, at worst fucked-up fucking weird. Maybe you should think yourself lucky. Some folks just aint worth getting involved with. And Leon sure is one of em.
I know his work better than I know him.
Huh! You could always try Suicide Bridge.  You dont know Leon, do you?
I take it you dont know where he is, then?
No shit... Well, Im afraid I cant help you.
Uh-huh.
I hear youre looking for Leon.  That makes me, his old-lady, and now you, looking for the little bastard. Leons gone, man. Vanished. You interested in his photographs?
Excuse me?
Welcome to the club.
If you can, send me a receipt.
We are so alike, Xavier. Still, sometimes I wonder which one of us is the ugliest.
I dont have your credentials, Nathalie.
Then why dont you reach him?
But maybe you know someone who does. An Austrian, in London, dealing in kids and snuff videos. How many can there be? These people supply to order. He has to be known, reachable.
A lachat, trois ou quatre mille. En location, cinq cent. Mais a pourrait faire plus. Je ne sais pas. Cest pas vraiment mon truc.  I dont know any Austrian, Xavier.
Le montage, lemballage. Not your regular street muck, is it? This is collectors stuff. How much would it cost me?
Alors quoi?
Alors?
Eh bien... Tes sr que tas besoin de moi?  La petite ma lair assez bien foutue, non?
Mon bureau cotait trop cher.
O est pass ton salon?
Bye. And thanks... Nathalie gently closes the door, eyes Lombard who shakes himself awake... rolls her eyes and surveys the room...
Tu sais o me trouver.
Jai bien peur quil te faudra attendre.  Pas avant la matine.
Viens.
Cinq cents.
Whats an hour of your time worth these days, Nathalie?  Combien, Nathalie!
Un Autrichien. Negociant en pr- pubescents.
Quest-ce que tu veux?
Huh. Im a businessman. What are you, eh?
Dont tempt me. The last scumbag who thought I might kill him died soon afterwards.
What you gonna do? Kill me?
Shut up and walk...
When they realise Im missing...
Thats what he said...
Youre sure he said his caller was a man?
Two stiffs and a missing kid followed your visit to one of the London hotels. He didnt need your confession...
What sums?
Some guy called to let him know the Frenchman whod called the night before he left London was in L.A. looking to kill him. He did his sums and decided to take the call seriously.
Not even scum like Friedman would go to the trouble of killing a stranger on the strength of one anonymous call.
I can only tell you what he told us...
Try again, and this time be polite.
Thats the beauty. An anonymous call. Makes you wonder how many people know what youre up to, eh, French-fuck?
So you killed him and went to clean out his hotel room... How did Friedman say he got to know where to find me?

Huh. Maybe he figured the news our London bureau got a visit from a hitman on behalf of a pissed off client wouldnt go down too well. He only shared his guilty secret last night. And then only cause he was so fucking edgy after calling his hotel we persuaded him to talk.
I think youd rather not know what I think.
What do you think, huh?
So why didnt he?
If he had, youd be dead.
Are you telling me Friedman didnt tell you I was here looking for him?

Thats just it. The sonofabitch didnt ask for help from his colleagues...  Testa di cazzo! Hiring some amateur outsiders to fix you... He hasnt gone to hell too soon... And neither will you, Mr Lamont!
Nice way to help a colleague in trouble.
Huh! You turned him into a liability, didnt you know?
Why did you kill him?
Let me give you a tip, asshole - no one pulls stunts like what you pulled in London and here tonight and hopes to get away with it. It upsets people. Its wrong. Fucking wrong.
Why did you kill Friedman?
Huh! Youve been around, eh?
The acid bath?
Youre the lantern man, huh?  If you wanna see whats left of him...
Glucks dead, you sonofabitch!
Three...
Fuck...
Five seconds. Then you die.
Figlio di puttana. Youre the French asshole who bumped off the London guys...
Gluck.
Who?  I dont know who the fuck youre talking about, sunshine.
Okay, shitbag. Im only going to ask you this once. Where is Friedman?
Its a good guess...
Mossad?

Their last suspected kill occurred two years back, though your Spitzes now probably do no more than bankroll the group. Still, Id watch my step. These people are well-connected, Laurent; former Israeli prime minister, etc. The ladys also president of an international Zionist organisation... Anyway, you get the picture.
Are they still operative?

It appears that in their younger days they were actively involved with a shady German group of Nazi hunters known as Never Forget. Over the years were talking about a dozen or so execution-type killings.
They lost their son. Why?
Salut, Laurent. Ouais. It wasnt easy but I got what you wanted through Interpol. Say, whats your business with these Spitzes?
Moreau? Cest moi. Alors...
Sure. But speak English, will ya, ha ha...
Very funny. Can I go on now?
I dont know. Could be the sound of jewellery hitting a parquet floor, huh?
What do you think?
Whats that? A word?
Costliest!
Cost what?

Ha ha... Yes. With prices reaching an all time low, the name of the game has become have-it- where-its-at... As we all know, transportation has always been the costliest and trickiest part of this business...
Tremoille... don't.  Please...
What do you fear most now... my sword?  ... or his hands?
No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?
But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her...
Jean, it's... it's not so easy...
We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape...
It's a miracle she's not dead!
Jeanne's been badly injured!  She jumped from the top of a tower into a frozen moat!
My dear Aulon...  That's fine...
10,000 gold crowns.
Very generous of you all.  How much?
Here... to help pay Jeanne's ransom. All the Captains gave what they could, as well as the citizens of Orleans and the other towns she saved...
Yes, my lord.
Jeanne, this is -- in fact -- my loyal friend and finest archer, Jean d'Aulon.  Jean... I place her in your care.  Find her suitable lodgings -- here -- in the castle... and guard her with your life.
So... pretend it's not a game.
Sire, you know how bad I am at this sort of game.
Good.  Until then, feel free to live like a king!
Of course I am, it's just that...
Why, are you not ready to die for your king?
Majesty, I can't...
My dear Aulon, to you it shall befall the honor of impersonating the royal blood!
My lord, I'm not sure that...
Why not you -- Jean d'Aulon?  The only man who's poorer than I am, and so the only man I can trust. Dignified, honorable, wise... what more could we ask of a king?
... if she can find me? -- That's a brilliant idea!  If she's really been sent by God she'll discover the trap, and if she's an assassin she'll kill the wrong man!  Bring her up!
Let someone else pretend to be you, and see if...
What do you mean?
That's a good idea, sire.
Oh dear, why is life so complicated? Sometimes I really wish I could be someone else.
Jeanne, you can't leave us like this!
I'm not afraid of the fire anymore. It will purify me...

No, you must come, Jeanne -- we need you -- so much has happened since you left... I have a new horse now, a white one, just like yours... and La Hire hardly swears at all anymore...  You can't stay -- they'll burn you!
I'm staying, Jean.
... and maybe the king will give you some money, and a little land, and a title even...  ... wouldn't that be a fine thing? You, a lady of title!
You don't know what you're saying. You're going to leave this place, Jeanne -- you're going home -- or whatever you want -- you're going to be happy, and have children, and...
One day you will.
I -- I don't understand...
My gentle Captain... I'm staying.
Yes yes... any moment... you're always so impatient...
I'm already free...
Just give me a moment and then you'll be free...
I am ready now...
That's an order!
I want to stay with you...
Do as I say!
But... why... what's the point?
Get back inside the town and see if the English are attacking from the other side!
Not yet!
We must sound the retreat!
It would not be the same without you.
Will you at least let me stay with you?
If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever.
To be killed in battle?
But it is what I want.
But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?
I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.
Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.
Jeanne... I have been hearing voices -- and believe me, those voices left me in no doubt that you must not go to Compiegne!
I will ask my voices... if they come back one day.  Meanwhile... I'm going to Compiegne.
To marry you.
Did you come back to marry me or to insult me?
Or maybe it's Jeanne who's in a trap -- her own trap -- a downward spiral that she can't stop?
No, but...
Did your voices tell you that?  You told me you hadn't heard them for months...
It's a trap!  They're buying time till they can bring over more soldiers from England!
He said that... he's making a treaty with the Duke of Burgundy and...
What did the king say?
You listen to your voices, I listen to my heart.
That's not what I asked... Why do you want to marry me?
Tell the king to give me more men.
Tell me...
If you really want to help me, there's one thing you can do.
Jeanne... I believe in you... more than anyone...
So... even you don't believe in me anymore...

Me?!  It's not me, it's God who makes everything complicated!  If he's all-powerful, why not let the English stay on their island in the first place?  And why let this war go on for a hundred years?  And why send you out to fight when a girl like you should be at home with your family?  Why, why?!
The truth is always simple... it's you, Jean, who's making things complicated.
You make it sound so simple...
I don't know it.  I feel it.
But how do you know what you hear is the truth?
All you have to do is stop talking and just listen.
But I hear so many voices... one voice saying one thing, another voice saying the opposite -- love your enemy, kill your enemy -- what is good, what is evil...?
Well of course they're me!  That's how God talks to me.  If you listen hard enough, even you can hear him. Everyone can hear him.
But how do you know that these -- these voices aren't really just -- well, you.
It's not time yet.  My mission is not over yet.  There is still more I must do before I can really -- finally -- go home.
Maybe their silence is a sign...? Maybe it's a sign to go home?
It's been weeks since they spoke to me.  Since the coronation... no signs... nothing...
What... what do you mean?
They've abandoned me... like everyone.
So... what am I supposed to do now?
Jeanne... the king has ordered us not to ride with you anymore.
Because there's an arrow in your leg.
Yes.  Yes, I'm fine...  We need more brushwood!  Why are you staring at me like that?
Jeanne...!  Are you alright?
Jeanne, no...
I'll go.
It's over, Jeanne.  We won, just as you said!
Yes...
Jeanne, calm down, do you hear me? Are you alright?
Come with me...
Well...
The king said you're his finest archer...?
I promise...
Alright... I promise to rest if you promise... to go back to the battle.
No, it's... it's nothing, it's...
Jeanne, you've been badly wounded...
Not so... easily.  Why aren't you... fighting...?  go on... we're almost there...
They've started the battle without me!
What's going on?!
But... to be honest... I don't think they'll leave tomorrow.
Good.
Uh... they said... they will think about it.
What did they say?
Alright, whatever -- but since He's not going to come down and cut it himself, at least let someone cut it properly!
How dare you tell me what God tells me to do!
He didn't tell you to cut all your hair off...!
How dare you stop me doing God's will!
Jeanne, stop it!
There's nothing to hear -- I haven't done anything.  And why haven't I done anything?  Because none of you will listen to me!!
Jeanne, calm down.  You can't blame the people -- they've been hearing all about you for weeks.
Who do they think I am?!
The King of England.  I want to give them the chance to leave Orleans in peace before I get there.
Yes, I am.  I'm an archer who can read and write.  Who do you want to write to?
I thought you were an archer?
This I can do.  I was studying at the University of Paris -- till the English invaded it.
I also need someone who can read and write.
Well... uh -- this might take a little time -- but let me see what I can do.
Better today than tomorrow.
Now?
I shall also be needing a war horse -- mine is too slow -- and armor -- and a good sword -- and an artist to make me a banner.
Right.  Raymond... a priest.
Yes.  I didn't confess today.
Now?
And I would like to see a priest.
Louis... water and fresh straw!
I would like some fresh straw.
Do you think I could have some water?
Listen, please accept my apologies for... you know, me pretending to be the... well it wasn't really my idea... well, yes it was my idea but...

I'm fed up with taking her orders. She swore she'd defeat the English before nightfall, instead of which she goes and plays the fool and gets herself nearly killed!  Look at the mess we're in!  That's her mess, not mine...!  We're worse off then if she'd never come at all!  ... now do as I say and Sound the Retreat!
But that was her order!
I made no such promise.  Sound the retreat for the night!
But I promised Jeanne we'd fight on!
Sound the retreat...
We have to press home the attack!
Good.
Jeanne's alive!
No, I... I never killed anyone!

... so you were in the middle of the battlefield, with your sword in your hand, waving it above your head... charging against the enemy, screaming and yelling... fighting for your life... and you want us to believe that in the middle of all this excitement you never killed anyone?
Yes, maybe... I don't remember...
You held up your sword and flourished it about in the air? Like this?
No, I... I held it up to...
Did you use the sword that you held in your hand?
Yes, but...
So sometimes you were carrying just your sword?
Yes, probably... maybe...
We have numerous witnesses who can confirm that you were not always carrying your banner...
No!  I warned the English to go back home -- I begged them not to force us to fight -- they knew the defeat I would bring on them... why didn't they listen to me?
Then perhaps the temptation to kill would have been stronger... too strong perhaps...?
No, of course not... I never killed anyone...
Are you saying that if you had not been carrying your banner you'd have killed more people?
To avoid killing anyone.
Why?
And so I... I prefer my banner.
And?
No, it's just... a sword is a weapon.
And why was that?  Did it have some particular value or power?
I was forty times more fond of my banner than my sword.
Which did you prefer, your banner or your sword?
Yes...
Didn't you also carry a banner?
Quite a few.
Do you have a sword?
I leave the answer to God.
Ah, yes, I forgot... God sent us an illiterate peasant to carry out such an important mission!  Do you think that God made the right decision, to take an ignorant girl to save the kingdom of France?
I can't read.
That is not what is written in the evidence... look for yourself!
No... I said "Surrender in the name of the King of France"...
And didn't you order the citizens of Paris to surrender the city in the name of the King of Heaven?
I don't know...
Do you think is was a good idea to launch an attack on a holy day?
I don't remember.  Maybe.
It was on a Sunday, wasn't it?
I tried to.
Is it true that you launched an attack on Paris?
I don't know, but you're all men of the church... why not ask Him yourself?
Good advice for the French, not for the English!  Do you think God hates the English?
Go onto the next question.
No.  But my revelations were for the King of France, not for you.
Did God forbid you to tell the truth?
No...
You're afraid of displeasing God when telling the truth?!
I won't tell you more about that. I'm more afraid of displeasing Him than not answering you...
Performing a miracle.
W-w-what are you doing?!
No no, you don't understand -- this is no ordinary oil -- this is miraculous... this oil was brought from heaven by a white dove to crown King Clovis in this... very... cathedral...
Thirty years ago?  I'm not surprised it's gone...
Well... at the coronation of King Charles VI...
And when was that?
I don't understand... the holy oil of Clovis... it was quite full the last time I saw it...

Oh yes, my lady.  All true kings of France must first be anointed in our great cathedral of Rheims... with the holy oil of Clovis... for it was within these very walls that Saint Remy received the sacred oil from Heaven, brought to him by a white dove for the anointing of King Clovis...
It is the sacred place that matters, Charles -- not the size.  Am I correct, Bishop?
Well find some other way!  Be creative.  Tell them she fucks the devil... Hmm, not a bad idea... why can't you say that?  Sounds good to me... and who can prove she doesn't?
I'm on the side of our Mother Holy Church.  Besides, a confession under torture will never convince anyone of her guilt.
Whose side are you on, Cauchon?
Scared to make a mistake.  Supposing she's right... supposing she really has been sent by God??
Scared of a girl?
You won't be able to drag anything from her that way.  You also must realize that many of my colleagues are... well, scared...
Well what are you waiting for? You've got a castle full of racks and ropes and pulleys:  go and torture the bitch!
But we can't do that unless she admits to blasphemy...
... and your prerogative is to find her guilty...
It is not for us to burn her, my lord.  That is your prerogative.

So long as this bitch remains alive, our armies refuse to fight!  Don't you understand?  They want proof that God is on their side... and the only way they're going to believe that is when they see her being burnt as a witch!
Be patient, my lord... you've seen how it is.  This girl has a way with people... but everyday we're making progress...
How can I calm down when I'm made the laughing-stock of the whole court?!  I've had enough!
Calm down, my lord, I beg you!
Well then?  Start proving... or else the church will have another martyr!
But in order to do so, the church must first prove her heresy, or else you'll be burning a martyr...
We want her burned as a witch!
But if this trial seems fixed, I fear you'll have the very opposite result to the one you want...
To hell with procedure!  We paid a bloody fortune for this slut, and we can do whatever the hell we like with her, whether the church likes it or not -- is that clear?
I understand your impatience, but if you want this trial to be acknowledged as legal we must follow correct procedure and...
She's loyal to her king... it's only to be expected that she...
Who's running this trial, you or her?  I can't believe it!  This wretched girl -- how dare she speak to us like that?
Rouen is in English territory.  I have the right to do anything I like.  Take them away.
What are you doing?  This is an ecclesiastical court -- you have no right to do this!
Arrest them!
And God who allowed you to be caught?
God defeated the English, not me.

Your king?  Ah yes, of course... What's he going to pay me with? Cows?  Chickens?  I prefer gold, and the English have plenty.  I wonder how much they'll pay... to have the Witch of Orleans in their clutches? Those English are so arrogant, they can't accept the idea of being defeated by a peasant girl... it has to have been the devil's work.
My king will pay any ransom you ask.
Guess.
Where... where am I?
Dead you're worthless, darling.
Am I... am I dead?
So... here is the famous Jeanne... Savior of Orleans... terror of the English?  You look pretty ordinary to me...
I'll be right here... I promise.
But where are you going to be?
Don't worry about me -- just stay in here... and don't move!
What about you?
Quick -- hide in here...
I was talking to the priest, and do you know what he said to me?
Really?
I was so worried -- we've all been looking for you!  The English are everywhere!  O thank you, lord!
No no, I'm fine, really...
Are you alright?  Did they hurt you?
I -- I can't Jeanne... I can't hear your confession... I'm sorry...
I ask only one thing... to hear me in confession...
It's not my body I want to save. It's my soul.
I know, Jeanne... it was the only way to save you from the fire!
And you?  Why did you lie?  You promised I could be confessed...
I don't understand, Jeanne... why did you do it?  Why?
Silence her!  Take her away...!
I didn't mean it!  I didn't know what I was signing!  You tricked me...!
You have nothing to regret...
Please... may I have it back...
As often as you like -- now, please -- for the love of God -- sign!!
And may I go to Mass?
Sign this, and I will confess you myself if you want.
No... I want to be confessed.
Jeanne, I beg of you... sign!  In God's name, don't you understand? I'm trying to save you!  If you don't sign, the English will burn you to death!  Is that what you want??
I am sent by God, and I submit all my words and deeds to His judgment. Or do you think that you are better judges than He is?
It is for us to determine whether you are a good Christian, not you.
So it is the Church Militant that refuses to confess me, and so prevents me from being a good Christian?

Let me clarify things for you, Jeanne.  On the one hand there is the Church Triumphant, that is to say God, his saints, and the souls that are saved.  And then there is the Church Militant, that is to say our Holy Father the Pope, the cardinals, the prelates of the Church, the clergy, and all good Catholic Christians.  Moreover this Church, when assembled, is guided by the Holy Spirit and therefore cannot be in error.  That is why we ask you to submit to the Church Militant... that is to say, us.
Is it here?  Now?  In this room?
Yes...
Tell us, Jeanne... do you often hear this voice?
Did it give you advice?  Good advice?
Many things...
What did it tell you?
Yes.
The voice was in your cell?
Praying.
What were you doing when the voice came?
Last night.
When exactly?  A day, a week -- when?
Not long ago...
I assure you they do.  So... answer me... when was the last time you heard this voice?
These questions have nothing to do with your trial.
Jeanne, you are not helping yourself.  If you don't answer our questions properly, your refusal will be taken into account.
And you be careful, you who claim to be my judges, for you too will be judged one day...!
Jeanne -- be careful -- you're not helping yourself by refusing to submit to our judgment...
Not unless you hear my confession.

Jeanne, listen to me very carefully. We are all men of faith, and we shall earnestly strive for the salvation of both your soul and body as though it were our own.  We do so in the name of our Holy Mother Church, who never closes her arms to those who would return to her.  But we cannot help you unless you submit to our learned judgment and authority.  Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?
Not unless you hear my confession.
Recite the Lord's Prayer.
Yes.  In the church at Domremy.
Were you baptized?
Nineteen... or thereabouts...
How old are you?
In a village called Domremy.
Show us a little more cooperation first.  Where were you born?
My name is Jeanne.  My little cross I had round my neck was taken away from me.  I would like to have it back.
So... begin by telling us your name -- assuming you're allowed to tell us that much?
I will willingly swear to tell you what I am allowed to tell you, but as to the rest, even if you threaten to cut off my head, I still won't tell you.
You must take the oath!  Not even a king, would refuse to take an oath to tell the truth in a matter of faith.
I will willingly swear to tell the truth about earthly things, but as for my revelations, I've never told anyone except my king... Charles the Seventh... the one and only king of France.
You will swear to tell the truth about whatever you are asked.
I don't know what you're going to ask me questions about.  You may ask things that I won't want to answer.
Take the Holy Gospels in your hand and swear to tell the whole truth concerning everything you will be asked.
Yes.  They paid your ransom... tomorrow you will be transferred to their great castle at Rouen.
The English??
It seems that the English care more about you than the French.
But... the King -- my king -- didn't he pay my ransom?
Your trial, Jeanne.  On a charge of heresy.
Trial?  What trial??
Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais. As you were captured in my diocese, the duty of conducting the trial falls upon me.
Who are you?
I will hear you... but not now, not here.
Oh, thank you Lord!  I'm so glad to see you!  I need to confess... I haven't been confessed since Easter... or been to Mass... Will you hear me now?
Don't look at the cost, look at what it brings.  What is your last offer?
20,000?!  But... I heard King Charles was... financially embarrassed.
I understand.  How much?

This word is -- regrettably appropriate for the situation.  In fact what we -- the Church -- wish to do is determine whether or not this girl is sent by God, as she claims.  You understand that we cannot allow just anybody to abuse God's name in this manner...
Buying her?
Not so well, I regret to say.  This business with the Maiden... it's caused him endless grief and torment.  That's why he's entrusted me with the task of... shall we say...
And your Duke?  The Duke of Bedford?
Thanks be to God.
He's feeling wonderful.
Good day, sir.  I trust my honorable Duke of Burgundy is feeling well?
Then her faith will have to be bigger.
But... her army's so small now...

Don't worry, Charles.  If God is still with her, she will be victorious.  We're not her judges... we're just spectators.  Let her go to Compiegne, as you let her go to Orleans, and let God decide her fate.
I... I can't stop her.

I assure you, Charles, the Maiden has no greater admirer than myself. But whatever our personal feelings, we cannot allow her to conduct her own private war.  For the sake of the kingdom, it is imperative that you stop her going to Compiegne...
It's true.  There's only one king... people need to be reminded of that. Nevertheless... Jeanne has done so much for us...
For the sake of France, Charles. And for the sake of my grandson.
You will??

You're a fine judge of character, Charles.  It'll take you less than five minutes to expose her if she's a fake.  But if she's not -- then she will give you your answers... and place the crown on your head.
You really think she's been sent... by God?
Who better than a messenger from God to give answers to your questions?
W-w-what has that got to do with this Maiden?
Mmmm.  Yes.  I know for example the sickness that plagues your heart.  I know how painful it is for you... to have loved a father... without ever knowing if he really was yours.
You think?
Your health and happiness has always been my first concern, Charles... ever since you were a little boy -- and I think I know you better than your own mother...
Why do you have to be so bloodthirsty?  Do you enjoy it?  All that blood and noise and pain? Diplomacy is far more civilized... far safer... and far cheaper...
Peace will only be got from the English at the end of a lance!

Well... we are, of course, enormously grateful for your past efforts, but your task is done.  Now it's time for negotiation... and after many months of skillful work, our dear Tremoille is about to seal a treaty with our Burgundian friends who will no longer lend their support to the English.  You see, my dear Jeanne... as it is written in the Bible, "to everything there is a season:  a time for war, and a time for peace"...
So how would you put it?
Gave you?  Well now, I wouldn't quite put it like that...
Why did you betray me?  Paris was ours for the taking!  All I needed was another few hundred men... Why did you take back the army you gave me?
Now hold on -- you're not captain here... on the battlefield perhaps, but not in the royal bedchamber!
Get them out of here!
... and my crown doesn't fit and...  Really??
... You look wonderful...
Ah, Jeanne... come here...!  This whole coronation idea of yours is a fiasco... nothing is ready...
Orleans has held out for six months. I don't suppose a few days will make much difference.  Take some rest.
I don't need lodgings if we're to be marching on Orleans...
He said that I have to save France from her enemies and give her back to God, and He told me that I -- Jeanne -- will lead you to the altar at Rheims to be crowned King of France.
... and what... what did he say?
I didn't wait long.  One day I was going to Mass, like I do every day, when the same strange wind started blowing again...
You did well...
What was my mission?  To help my country?  But how could I do that? I was only a poor girl who knew nothing about riding or making war... so I decided to wait and not to speak to anyone about it.
I know you're not yet -- but you will be, soon.
I'm... I'm not the king...
There's no need to be afraid, sire.
Noooo!
I... I don't know... it'll sound like we... betrayed her...?
Let them come!  Let them see who's the true king of France!
There's no time, sire -- we can't hold up the ceremony... there's no telling when the English might come back... they're only ten leagues away...
He's probably right -- let's call a delay...
No doubt your captains will fight for your fine cause -- but what about the ordinary soldier?  They don't fight for causes these days. They fight for money.  Who's going to pay them?
My captains have sworn their support.
... to ensure our privacy.  I need to talk to her.  Alone.
... as always, majesty...
My dear loyal Tremoille, I know I can count on you...
Your majesty, I really think you...
Tremoille, I'm not even king yet... who'd want to assassinate me?
