Supposing she's an assassin?
My astrologers assure me that the hour is p-p-propitious -- Leo, with Virgo rising.  Have you ever noticed on the astrological chart how the Virgin is next to the Lion?
Your majesty, I urge you not to see this woman.  It all reeks of a Burgundian trap!
The other half.
I can see her if I want to.  I mean, with half of France in the hands of the English, what have I got to lose?

Not exactly.  She wants you to give her an army -- at your expanse.  Bearing in mind that your mother stole every last piece of gold in the treasury, I fail to see how you can afford such an adventure.
If she comes from Burgundy it makes a difference.  It might be a trap...  Look... Signed "X".  What sort of name is "X"?  Or must we conclude that a messenger of God can't even write her own name?
What difference does it make where she comes from?
You mustn't see her, my lord.  We know nothing about her... we don't even know if she is from Lorraine.
She says she'll be here tomorrow...!
She pretends she's been sent by God! These charlatans -- it's a pity there isn't enough wood to burn them all!
That's enough!  You will answer the question... or face the consequences!
Go on to the next question.
But if the devil were to take on the physical appearance of a saint or an angel... or a man... how would you recognize him?  By what he said?
I'm more interested in what he says, not what he looks like.
Is it long and hanging down?
Yes.
Does he have hair?
His face.
You told us about the appearance of this... voice.  What exactly did you see?  Part of it... or all of it?
Go and ask him yourself.
Then why did your king believe in you without any proof?
If there was, I didn't see it...
When you saw your king for the first time, was there an angel over his head?
I must offer to the Duke.  I will give you his answer tomorrow.
8,000.  We can't raise more... We can only place ourselves at the mercy of your generosity.
20,000 gold crowns.
May I, without offending you, inquire how generous?
I know... but the English want her very badly, and I have to tell you that they are proving much more generous.
It is all his majesty can afford. He has even donated his very own personal savings.  His majesty will greatly appreciate a gesture of good will in this delicate negotiation between our two families.
That's not a lot.
5,000 gold crowns.
The English won't wait.
Not yet.
Well...?  Shall we go?
The bridge won't wait!
We need another ten minutes...
Stand by with the battering-rams...
I know what I'm doing, so either lend a hand or go back to bed!
Jeanne, what are you doing with that... you've got it back to front...
We're taking back the Tourelles!
What's going on?
The wind will be with us!  Do as I say.
The wind will be against us...
Position the long-bows over there, crossbows over there -- and set up Dijon Culverins either side of those trees...
Sooner is better than later!
Can we -- uh -- discuss this later?
Dunois... was it you who ordered the attack?  Answer me?!
Knowing what I know?  Enormous gratitude.
Jeanne, put yourself in my shoes for a moment -- how would you feel, if you were me?
Ah, so that's it.  To you I'm just a girl.
Jeanne, you have to understand -- it's not easy for us -- I mean for our pride -- to suddenly be usurped by a -- well, with all due respect, by a... girl.
"Be patient, be patient"... is that the only advice you can ever come up with??  I've shown more patience than a dozen saints!

What complicated about it?  All you have to do is do what you're told -- what could be simpler than that? I'm the drum on which God is beating out his message -- beating so loudly it's bursting my ears -- but you're all so full of your own voices, you're deaf to His!
Jeanne, with respect -- we can't just attack the Tourelles like that -- it's a very complicated matter and...
You know, I feel a great sorrow for you, because you're laughing now, but by tomorrow night some of you will be dead and having to repeat your jokes in front of God.
God.

Jeanne, that really makes no sense at all.  The Tourelles is virtually impregnable... besides, if we're on the other side of the river attacking the Tourelles, what's to stop Talbot attacking the city from the north?
We offer the English a last chance to return home in peace.  If they refuse, we recross the river and attack them here -- at the Tourelles.
So... what is the message?

Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you.
You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!

Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything.
Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!

Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?
For what?
Wait, wait...
He's on the other side of the river.
Good.  Can you bring me to him?
I know...
It's coming -- I rode on ahead.  I have to speak with the Captain of the English army... his name's Talbot...
Everywhere.  Where is the food?
Good.  Where are the English?
Yes... they were.
Were you sent by Lord Dunois?
As long as she brings food and supplies, she'll be welcome.
But... don't you think we should at least... go and... welcome her?
Xaintrailles...!  Don't talk to me about miracles...  If I was still sitting there waiting for a miracle, I'd be dead now. Anyway...
And it's not the first one!  They say she saved a little boy who was dying of...
Yes, it's a miracle.
The Dauphin -- he's sending us food -- and supplies -- and an army -- led by Jeanne -- the maiden from Lorraine -- isn't it wonderful?!
Calm yourself, Xaintrailles.  Now slowly.  Who has finally done what?
My lord Dunois... I have wonderful news! -- finally -- he's sending her to us -- thanks be to God -- we're saved -- it's wonderful!
No good?  This is a disaster!
This is no good!
Good idea...
Yes.  We can pray.
There must be something we can do for her for Chrissakes!
Me too...
I do love her when her fire gets well and truly stoked!
Oh, but I forgot!  It was a Sunday... that explains it.  God's day off.
Damn right!
God... why of course -- we'd forgotten about him!  Strange, I don't seem to remember seeing him at Agincourt.
That'll put fire in my soldiers!
Brilliant idea... but to be really effective, why not send a whole army of virgins?
To hell with your voices -- it's time to face facts!  We have nothing to do here... none of us... not even you.  You should go home, Jeanne.
But my voices... they promised me...
He never sent them... Don't you understand?  He doesn't want this war anymore... he has his crown now, that's all he ever wanted...
But... where is Dunois... where are the men the king promised me?
Jeanne... that is not ten thousand reinforcements -- that is one hundred very loyal but very tired soldiers.
Of course I do?  Bring them up!
Do you know how to count?
Never look behind -- only ahead!
Jeanne, look behind you.
Right behind us -- Dunois with another then thousand men!
Reinforcements?  Where??
So... bring up the reinforcements!
Jeanne... we're not enough...
I know, but so is the enemy -- they're falling back -- Paris is ours...!
Jeanne... The men are exhausted!
Maybe... I don't know... but first we have to confess...
Bravo!  What about all the other hundreds of prisoners?  Do we let them go too?
I care!  And I care because God cares!  All life is precious to God -- even his -- even yours and mine...
Jeanne... let him do it.  One more dead body's not going to make any difference, so who cares?
For weeks you've been asking for this... well now you have it!
No... not like this...
You look disappointed... Isn't this what you wanted?
Perfectly.
Clear?
The English are rebuilding it.
But the bridge has been pulled down!
We return to Orleans... across the bridge, at the Tourelles.
I don't think.  I leave that to God. I'm nothing in all this, I'm just the messenger.
And... what does Jeanne think?
It seems to me that the Church and Our Lord are one and the same.  Why must you complicate what is so simple?
But will you also submit to the decision of the Church?
I... submit to Our Lord.
So you think you did well to cut your hair and dress as a man?
It was just... more convenient as I was among soldiers...
You also cut your hair short like a man, and in the Bible it clearly states that it is an abomination for a woman to pretend to be a man!  It proves your desire to deceive...
The clothes are not important...
Who told you to wear men's clothes?
Oh?  Perhaps someone pushed you then?
No!
And you didn't jump of your free will?
Yes, but...
You mean it was not of your own free will that you were on the ledge?
I know, but that's not the way things happened...
Do you not know that suicide is a very grievous sin?  No one is allowed to destroy the life that God created!
That's now what I meant...
How can you deny it when you just said "I'd rather die than fall into the hands of the English"...?
So when you jumped, you wanted to kill yourself?
No...
Did your voice tell you to jump?
I had been sold to the English.  I'd rather die than fall into their hands.
Tell us, Jeanne... why did you jump from the tower at Beaurevoir?
Here -- take this instead.
Yeah...
That's different... I mean... we were fighting for a... for a cause!
Besides, what about these...?
Because... because you just can't!
Why not?  He has good teeth...
But you can't just kill a man for his teeth!
Nothing... just taking his teeth.
Stop it!  What are you doing?
We still believe in you, Jeanne.  If it were up to me, I'd chase every goddamn Englishman into the ocean. But it's not up to us anymore -- it's up to the king...
You don't believe me anymore?
I said, kneel!
Jeanne, if you don't mind... I'll stay standing... this armor... it's a nightmare to get back up...
A few teeth... that's the price of his life?
Jeanne... the man hasn't been paid for six months -- that's his only reward.  Let him take a few teeth...
If you kill him, you kill me!
Jeanne... get up... this is ridiculous...
Take mine instead -- here -- smash mine first!
It's not possible...
... the smell of victory, Jeanne! Mmmmmmm!  I love it!
You call this... glory...?  All this... this blood... this smell of...
Won?!  Such a small word will never do!  This is victory, Jeanne, this is... glory!
We... won?!
Not for long...
What's the use?  The drawbridge is up!
Prepare these as battering-rams!
I'd sooner die than use magic!
Physicians are a waste of time. You'll have more luck with this charm of mine... it saved my life at Agincourt!
Don't swear...
I swear I'll never swear again in my life if you save her life!  But I'm warning you, if you let her die, then you're the biggest...
Were the men confessed?  Where are the priests?
God knows, but it was a bad idea!
What happened?  Who gave the order to attack?
They will -- and so will you if you go on swearing like that.
Jesus Christ... the goddamn English will pay for this!
Then, Lord Dunois, show me the way to the other side of the river...
Jeanne, let me introduce the king's half brother, the dogged Lord Dunois.
Sorry Jeanne...  Did you both meet already?
La Hire, I'm warning you -- don't swear!
Hey, my friend!  I'm glad to see your ugly damn face again!
So who gave the order to bring me to this side of the river??
And you look pretty wealthy for a servant of God, wouldn't you say?
Still, pretty wealthy for a peasant girl wouldn't you say?
Yes, I was given a few, but I never had time to wear them...
What about all those dresses you were given... silk dresses weren't they?
No.
As much as for a Lord?  What an honor!  Did your king give you other wealth apart from horses?
Five steeds and a few hackneys...
How many did he give you?
My king.
Who gave you that horse?
Yes... a half-steed... white.
When you were taken prisoner at Compiegne, did you have a horse?
Let's see.
Yes, my lord.
You think you are ready now?
No...
You know what you just signed, Jeanne?  You just signed away my existence... For you I'm a lie, an illusion.  You see?  In the end, you were the one who abandoned me...
... to love your enemy as much as you love yourself?
Yes...
Are you willing to follow all His commandments?
Yes I am.
Do you think you are ready?
There's nothing for me to do here anymore... I don't belong here I want to be with Him now...
Are you sent by God?
Yes... of course... when you don't need me anymore.
Are you going to leave me too?
I don't think so.
My voices... my voices... do you think they will ever come back?
Good.  But "love your enemies"... body and soul.
"Love your enemies"...
No, I...
Do you think this cross will protect you?
Because... because I don't know what else to do to please him.
What for?
I'm trying to make my cross look more beautiful...
What are you doing on the wall?
I -- I cleaned up my room, look... and I said my prayers... all of them... and...
Really?
I never took pleasure in hurting anyone?
Ah, pleasure... that's a difficult word to define.  When does the pain end and the pleasure begin...? When did your pleasure begin with that sword in your hand...?
Why are you doing this to me??  Do you get pleasure from hurting me?
I don't agree.  Why do you have to keep changing your mind all the time?
I agree...
No, I do not think so.  I don't think that killing each other will ever bring peace.
No, no, you did fine.  I'd even say well done.  Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?
I... I was defending myself as best I could!  Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they?  Or should I have let myself be killed?
"Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned?  Come on Jeanne, be honest.  You fought for yourself, in your name.
Really?
Yes!  We fought and killed in His name... the King of Heaven!
In His name??
No, but... why didn't he stop it? Or did he get pleasure, watching us killing each other in his name?
Is he the one who spread all this blood and misery?

Yes... yes!  And now you tell me why God let all these battles happen in the first place... if he's so powerful... he said he's "the creator of heaven and earth, the source of all life..." he could have easily stopped all this blood and misery?  Why didn't he?
So your memory's coming back?

Stop, stop... I can't remember!  The battles were all so confusing... there was so much smoke, dust, noise... I was being attacked on all sides, so... maybe... perhaps I fought back but it was only to defend myself...
Oh no?  How about this one?
No!  I don't want to know anymore! Leave me alone!  I didn't kill that man!
Oh?  You can't remember?  Let me help your memory...
I'm not lying, I... I can't remember... leave me alone!
True -- every event has an infinite number of causes -- but why pick one rather than another?  There are many ways a sword might find itself in a field...
But... it didn't just get there by itself.
No.  That was a sword in a field.
Like... like the wind... and the clouds... and... the bells... and what about that sword lying in the field... that was a sign...!
What signs?
No, but... he sent me so many signs!
You mean God said, "I need you, Jeanne?"
Yes... lots of things!
God asked you to do something?
Because!  Because I've always been faithful to God, and I've followed everything he said... and I've done everything he asked me...
Why would they?
What do you mean, they won't come?
They won't come anyway.
Because... I have to be alone!
Why not?
No, no -- you can't stay or they won't come!
I want to see that.  Do you mind if I stay... on the side?  I won't bother you.
Yes... that's what I pray for...!
They're going to come and visit you in here?
My... visions...
Who?
Yes!
Why?  Are you waiting for someone else?
What are you doing here?  Please... leave... you can't stay here...
Why were you yelling like that?!
I told you already... I'm here to set you free...
I don't understand.  What do you want from me?
Oh, so you don't want war anymore? You want to be at peace?  You want to be able to change your mind anytime you feel like it and expect everyone to go along with it?
I don't know -- I don't care anymore -- I just want to be at peace!
Oh?  And just because you realize now, everybody else should forgive you?!
No, no... I'm just so tired, and lost, and... I didn't realize what I was doing!
That's too easy.  One minute you want to die, the next you want to live...  Do you think that life is a toy that can be played with and then broken when you don't want it anymore?

How can you pretend that you love God when you're about to throw away the most precious thing he gave you? Life is a gift, you should know that by now Jeanne -- a gift from God. You know what He'd say to you, if He was here?  "What are you doing to me, Jeanne?"
I am true -- to my Lord, the King of Heaven.  He knows how much I love him -- that's all that matters to me...
If you were true to yourself... if your faith was firm, you wouldn't need to run away from yourself like this...
I... I never lied!
You'll be dead soon enough anyway, so why be in such a hurry?  Why not face up to your lies?  It's your lies you can't stand anymore...
Everything!  Prison -- humiliation -- being abandoned and betrayed by everyone -- I can't stand it anymore -- I'd rather die!
And what exactly is it that you can't take anymore of?
I... I'm leaving... I can't take anymore...
I might ask you the same question.
What are you doing out here?
Nothing.  I'm here to set you free...
I... don't know... what do you want from me?
WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE IF YOU SHOULD LIVE OR DIE?
I don't know... please... tell me I'm dead...
YOU THINK GOD ISN'T BIG ENOUGH TO DELIVER HIS OWN MESSAGES?
I don't know... I thought...
No... no... I'm just a messenger... He needs me... a higher calling...
Who are you to even think you can know the difference between good and evil?  Are you God?
I am that I am.  You don't like my face?  Maybe you prefer this one...
Who... who are you...?
What have you done to me?
Playing...
Jeanne... what are you doing?
I want to be at one with Him now.
Soon you'll be able to take the Holy Mass, and as you eat of his flesh and drink of his blood, you will be at one with him.
I want to be with him always...
Jeanne, be patient.
I don't want to wait for his call.
Jeanne... calm down...!  Calm down, Jeanne!

Then what will?  And what will bring her back?  And why did she have to die in the first place instead of me?  Why didn't he take my life instead of hers?  It was my fault -- I was late -- she gave me her hiding place...!!
I realize your anger, Jeanne, but we must learn to forgive.  It's hard, but revenge will never bring about peace.
I know Jesus says to love our enemies but I can't -- I just want the English to burn in hell for ever and ever!
Only God knows the answer to that.
Why did she have to die?
I heard about your sister, and I... understand your pain...
Perhaps... but wherever he comes from, I think you should listen to him, because it sounds like he's giving you very good advice.
He says... he says I must be good... and help everyone... and take care of myself.  Do you think he's coming from the sky?
And what does he say to you?
Beautiful.
What... does he... look like?
He never says his name.
Who is this "he"?
Well, I try and talk to him, but mostly he's the one who does the talking.
Him?
I feel safe here.  And it's where I can talk to him.
Then... why are you here so often?
Yes, it is.
So... everything sounds... wonderful?
Oh yes, I play with them... lots...
And what about your other friends... you don't like playing with them?
Oh yes, my sister's just... she's... wonderful.
Good, good.  And your sister... Catherine -- she's still your best friend?
Oh yes, she's... wonderful.
And your mother -- everything's fine with her?
Oh yes... very.
Well no, but... Jeanne, are you happy at home?
Is that bad?
Jeanne -- if we were to ask forgiveness all the time, we'd spend our whole life in church.
He already did, but I want God to forgive me too.
I'm sure he'll forgive you.
My father's.
Whose were they?
They weren't my shoes.  Mine were too small.
There's no sin in charity, Jeanne.
I saw a poor monk without shoes so I gave him some.
So... alright.  What terrible sin have you committed since then that can't wait till tomorrow to be forgiven?
I need to confess again.
But you already confessed this morning...
I need to confess.
You know I'm always happy to see you, Jeanne, but to keep coming here twice, three times a day...
Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews.
A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her.
A beauty. Who is she?
Yes.
Someone you know?
It's like this... I...we...all of them.
Why are you here, Mr. Wladek?
Who wants me to stop?
I'm sorry, Mr Wladek, he wants you to stop.
He's still a doctor.
Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician.
I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him.
You can't, it's too dangerous.
I'm going to get a doctor.
Oh, yes. I remember.
This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him.
Christmas.  This is not a good time to have children. But then...
When's your baby due?
Dead.
And how's Yurek?
Just over a year.
How long have you been married?
He'll be here soon.
I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay.
He'll be back before curfew.
I need help.
Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.
I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr--  -- a Mr Dzikiewicz.

He had his chance and all he did was shoot up a rooming house.  Made a lotte noise and woke up a few cops, but didn't hit nothin'.
He's not comin' in.  Not to get bounced off a job anyway.
And tell Cole I wanta see him when he gets in.
Use Salino.  It'll take a little longer, but there won't be any holes in it.
They didn't think he'd be so cagey, that's all.  They'll get him next time.
Then why ain't he dead?
Salino?  Why waste our best people on a small-time job like this?  It ain't no heavy gee we're after. The guy's a five and dime grifter.
We'll put Salino on it.  I need somebody careful.
We'll be waitin'.
I just got the count.  We'll put the take on the 4:15.
They did 14 grand in Evanston, 16.5 is Gary, and 20 in Cicero.  Looks like you're bringing up the rear, Granger.
Well, hell, you got the whole Chicago south side.  How do ya expect the eight lousy spots I've got to compete with that?
We cleared 22 here.
Believe me, the Man's gonna be real happy.  Looks like we cleared over ten grand this week.
Okay, finish your count and get it up here as soon as you can.  I don't wanta be here all night.
Hell yes.  He does this every year. There's nothing to worry about.
You been making your payoffs, haven't ya?

We had a few problems with the Law this morning.  The Mayor promised the Jaycees to get tough on the rackets again, so he shut everybody down for a couple hours to make it look good.  Nothing serious, it just put us a little behind for the day.
Granger, this is Combs.  Why haven't we heard from ya?  Everybody else is in.
Shove off, Duff.
He was a tear-off rat.  He got what he deserved.  No sense helpin' pay his bills.
He was a con man, wasn't he?
Wasn't no problem a mine.
You the Duff that didn't come up with his end when Little Jeff was sent up?
Buck Duff.  I was in Maxwell's boost in Troy.
Listen to me, Hooker.  What ever you do, don't go back to your place tonight, don't go anyplace you usually go, ya hear me?  Get outa town or somethin', but...
Aw Christ, it doesn't make no difference now.  If Snyder knows about it so does everybody else. He never gets anything first...Damn, there's no answer at Luther's.
What the hell you gonna do when Snyder rushes his finger right to Lonnegan?  You're committin' suicide, kid.
I did.  That stuff I gave him was counterfeit.  They'll pinch him the first place he tries to spend it.
I thought you blew all your money.
Forget it.
I don't look any good in clothes and I don't know how to drive. What else ya got to sell, Eirie?
You could buy yourself some things. Clothes, or a nice car...
I like griftin'.
If you saved a little, you wouldn't have to grift so much.
There's always a depression on.
You ain't gonna have nothin' if you don't lay off them games of chance. There's a depression on ya know.
We were partners.  If it weren't for Luther I'd still be hustlin' pinball down at Gianelli's.  I don't need anything more than I got.
Aw come on, it was the only thing to do.  He knew he was holdin' ya back.
How do you like that Coleman, huh? After three years.
The bastard.  He can blow his nose all the way.
Straight north.  He was gonna take it all and run.
Which way did he do, Eirie?
Hey, Luther told me he was carrying a wad, but I didn't figure this much.
What am I supposed to do?  Call him for cheating better than me?
I know I give him four threes.  We can't let him get away with that.
Nothin'.  They gotta be outa there early.  I'm gonna bust that bastard in one play.
What do ya want the others to get?
I don't care.  Load me a deck.  Set it up for threes and nines.  I'll cut it in on his deal.
You've only been playin three hours, Doyle.
I've had it with that bum, Floyd. Stack me a cooler.
Good lad.
Yes sir.

Name's Danny McCoy.  No Neck McCoy we called him.  Runs a few protection rackets for Carnello while he's waiting for something bigger to come along.  Me and Danny been friends since we were six. Take a good look at that face, Floyd, cause if he ever finds out we let one lousy grifter beat us, you'll have to kill him and every other hood in Chicago who'd like to do the same thing.  You understand what I'm sayin'?
They staked out the other guy's place last night, but he never showed.  They figure maybe he skipped town.  You wanna follow 'em up?
Hackers.
Combs gave it to Reilly and Cole.
Who's got the contract?
They're still looking for him.
What about the other one?
We got word from Chicago.  They got one of the grifters last night. The nigger.

All right, mark Mottola up a little and put him on a bus.  Nothin' fancy, just enough to keep him from coming back.  Get some local people to take care of the other two.  We gotta discourage this kinda thing.
I don't know.  Could be.  We're runnin' that down now.
They workin' for anybody?
No, we checked his story with a tipster.  He was cleaned by two grifters on 47th.
You sure he didn't just pocket it?
Mottola.
Which one?
It's important.  We had a little trouble in Chicago today.  One of our runners got hit for 12 grand.
I'm busy, Floyd.
Doyle, can I see you a minute?
All he's gotta do is read.
Does J.J. know how to use this thing?

We bought ya a tap into Moe Anenberg's wire.  He's got eyes at every track in the country.  You'll get race results, odds, scratches, pole positions, everything; and just as fast as Western Union gets 'em.
Just give us what ya can, Benny. We'll send a truck down.
You want the stuff tomorrow or don't ya?  It's gonna take hours just to clean it up.  Besides, Gondorff's still a hot item.  Where am I gonna be if he gets hit?
C'mon, you can do better than that. We ain't no heel grifters.

All right, I'll rent ya everything I got in the warehouse for two grand.  That'll give ya phones, cages, blackboards and ticker gear. You supply the guys to move 'em. If you want a counter and bar, that's another grand.  I don't know where the hell I'm gonna get 'em though.
All we need is the bookie setup for now.  We'll worry about the telegraph office later.
Been a while since I stocked a wire store.  Not many mobs playing that anymore.
Got to.  Gondorff's ridin' the mark in from New York on the Century.
I don't know.  This is kinda short notice.  I'm not sure we can get it all done by Saturday.
Looks all right.  It's big enough and off the street.
Naw, I'd just blow it.
You wanta wait for your share?
You were right, Henry.  It's not enough... But it's close.
You beat him, kid.
Ain't nothin' gonna make up for Luther, kid.  Revenge is for suckers.  I been griftin' 30 years and never got any.
I appreciate your stickin' your neck out.  I wouldn't have asked ya if it weren't for Luther.
Yeh.
Henry.
Seems worthwhile, doesn't it? Maybe it's just for the cave-in on Lonnegan's face when we put in the sting.
Then why you doin' it?
I better do some packin'.  I'm gonna be a hot number again after tomorrow.

Two or three hundred I guess. Sometimes played two a day when I was in Shea's mob.  We had it down to a business.  'Course Chicago was a right town then.  The fix was in.  The dicks took their end without a beef.  All the Wall Street boys wanted to make investments for us.  Even had marks looking us up, thinkin' they could beat the game.  Yeh, kid, it really stunk.  No sense in bein' a grifter if it's the same as bein' a citizen.
How many guys you conned in your life, Henry?
Take it easy, you won't lose him now.  We had him 10 years ago when he decided to be somebody.  Believe me, I've seen enough to know.
Luther always told me to bite my toenails when I get nervous.  You see yourself doin' that and you realize it ain't worth it.
Just a little nervous, that's all.
What's the matter, kid?  You're not sayin' much.
Christ, they'll probably miss you and hit me.
A couple days; that's all I'm askin'.  I can stay clear that long.

You just won't learn, will ya. Hell, you come in here, I teach you stuff maybe five guys in this world know, stuff most grifters couldn't do even if they knew it, and all you wanna do is run down a bullet.  You're just like all them new jerks. Lotsa nerve and no brains.  And ten years from now when me and the others are through and you dumb guys are all dead there won't be one gee left who knows the Big Con was anything more than a way to make a livin'.
All we need is a couple days, Henry. A couple days and we'll get Lonnegan down and stomp on 'em.
You know how easy it'd be for one of Lonnegan's guys to nail you?
You can't play your friends like marks, Hooker.
It was too noisy.
Then why'd ya move outa your room?
Nothin'.  I told ya everything there is.
Well you found him again and we're gonna have to do somethin' about it. What else haven't ya been tellin' me?
I thought I'd lost him.
Why didn't you tell me about Snyder before?
He'll show.
No.
Did he say he wouldn't?
You think he'll show?
Did he hold you up on anything?
Then he drove me home.  He tried to put himself away as legit, so I went right into the pitch.
Hell, they don't do that and you know you're not gettin' through to 'em.
He threatened to kill me.
And?
I gave him the breakdown just like ya told me to.
How 'bout Lonnegan?
No, not a thing.
You know, somebody tailin' ya.  A torpedo or somethin'.
What do ya mean?
No signs of trouble?
Yeh, it was easy.
Everything go all right?
Well we got some workin' money anyway.
How'd ya do?
If we ever get to it.
You just worry about your end, kid.
Let him wait.
He's waitin' for you in the card room.
Neither are we.
He's not as tough as he'd like to think.
If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got.
Then you'll do it?
Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death.
You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?
You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more.
I never played for winos.
This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy.
We'll get by without 'em.
You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good.
'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him.
Why?
I'll take him anyway.
And a packing company, a chain of Savings and Loans and half the politicians in Chicago and New York. There ain't a fix in the world gonna cool him out if he blows on ya.
Aw right, he runs the numbers outta the south side.
Yeh, he croaked Luther.  What else do I gotta know.
You know anything about him?
I wanna play for Lonnegan.
You didn't act much like you wanted to learn it.
Gondorff, you gonna teach me the Big Con or not?
You never do, kid.
I don't know.  Haven't seen anybody.
Lonnegan after you, too?
I picked something up on the way.
You gonna stay for breakfast, or do you already know how to eat?
No, I lammed it around for a while while things cooled off.  Philly, Denver, Baltimore, nuthin' towns.
He didn't tell me you was a fuck- up, either.  You played the Big Con since then.
Luther didn't tell me you had a big mouth.
You mean you blew it.
Aw, I conned a Senator from Florida on a stocks deal.  A real lop-ear. He thought he was gonna take over General Electric.  Some Chantoozie woke him up, though, and he put the feds on me.
He had you down as a big-timer. What happened?
I'm sorry about Luther.  He was the best street worker I ever saw.
Yeh, Luther said you could teach me something.  I already know how to drink.
Glad to meet ya, kid.  You're a real horse's ass.
I can talk, can't I?
You sober?
Turn the goddamn thing off, will ya.
He wants to put a half million on Syphon.
What's the problem?
If we're lucky, this'll bring him back stronger than ever.
Looks like he's sulking.
Get a couple extra guys in the line, then.  We'll give him the shut-out.
Not enough to cover a bet that big.
He's gonna hit ya with 20 grand, Eddie.  How much cash we got?
I also gotta win.
All you gotta do is show up with some money and look like a fool.
That's why he won't know it.
The wire is ten years outa date.
We'll use the wire.  Never known a gambler who wouldn't like to beat the ponies.
Fancies himself a gambler, huh?
The porters say he runs a braced card game in one of the cars.  $100 minimum, straight poker.  Last time he pulled in here ten grand heavier than he left New York.
Wonder why he doesn't fly both ways.
He's been taking the 8:10 Century Limited outa New York on Friday and getting in here early Saturday morning.  He usually stays a day to check on his policy operations, and then flies back.
Nothin' yet.  I got a good one on the lead at Hialeah, but he's fadin'.
How ya doin'?
That's what I like about these guys, J.J... They always got protection against things we'd never do to 'em.
Look at that.  He's got four apes with him.
Nice work, J.J.
He usually plays with a Royal or a Cadenza.  I got you one of each.  He likes to cold deck low, 8's or 9's.
Yeh, I think so.  I gave the kay- ducer a C-note.  You find out the deck?
You in?
We'll give him the hook on the train, and play him here.  You think I can get in that poker game, Eddie?
I'm not sure I know it.
Everybody'll sit still for somethin'. What did ya find out about the train, Eddie?
Lonnegan's a fast egg, Henry.  He's not gonna sit still for a standard play.
You're more gutless than I thought.
A half mill on an eight to one shot. You're dumber than I thought, Lonnegan.
What are the odds on Syphon?
If ya win it could make ya, too.
I can't lay that off in time.  We lose a bet that big, it could break us.
Make sure you see cash from this guy, Eddie.  He's got the name for bettin' money he don't have.
The name is Lonnegan.
Never get enough, huh pal?  I'd think you'd get tired of losin', Honnigan.
What!  Don't give me that crap you little weenie.  How do I know you ain't gonna take a powder.  You come to a game like this, you bring your money.
I guess I left it in my room.
Raise 5,000.
See and raise 1,000.
Raise 500.
Raise 1,000.
Pass.
Raise 300.
Five and call.
See and raise five.
See ya and raise three.
Raise 500.
Lonnegan.
Yeh, that'd be real nice of ya, Mr. Lonneman.
Don't have much choice, do ya?
How do I know you're tellin' the truth.
Gondorff asked me to look after ya.
Who are you?
Too many people coulda seen ya go in her room.  She was a professional. Used to work in the Dutch Schultz gang.
She coulda killed me last night.
Then you'll have to come up with another grand somewhere.
My end was only one.
Nobody can buy you a prayer, if I put the finger on ya.
I'll square it with the fixer.
Not intentionally maybe, but that don't make no difference to Lonnegan. He'll swat you like any fly.
You're crazy.  I'm not stupid enough to play for rackets money.

I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on 49th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect.
Aw, find yourself a shoplifter to roll.
You scored blood money today, Hooker.  You need a friend.
Hi there, Snyder.  Things a little slow down at the Bunco Department tonight, eh?  Somebody lose the dominoes?
Think nothin' of it.
Thank you.  You don't know how much I appreciate this.

All right, I'll give ya a break.  Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left.  Go on in there and wait at the window. I'll take this...  ...in the back and run it through right away.  We'll have you outta there in a couple minutes.
I'm sorry, really I am, but my train leaves in ten minutes.

We'll get 'em!  Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here, ya know.  We go around advertising ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh?  You think I'm wearin' this rag here 'cause I like it?  Christ, everybody thinks life's a holiday or somethin' when you got a badge.  I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes.
But what about all these other people?
It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall.
But I got a train to make.
Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?
Yes, a ticket to Chicago.
We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station.  Have you made any purchases here today?
What for?  I haven't done anything.
Excuse me, sir.  Treasury Dept... I'd like to ask you a few questions.
You know me.  I'm just like you... It's two in the morning and I don't know nobody.
I don't even know you.
If I expected somethin', I wouldn't be still standin' out here in the hall.
And you expect me to come over, just like that.
I don't mean nothin' by it.  I just don't know many regular girls, that's all.
You move right along, don't ya.
I, ah...thought you might wanna come out for a while.  Maybe have a drink or somethin'.
Yeh, this time anyway.
Looks like he missed ya.
He'd like to kill me.
What does this guy want?
Just do what I tell ya and everything'll be jake.
What the hell for?
All right, do me a favor.  Go into the bathroom, open the window and wait for me there.
No.
Look, I don't have time to fuck around.  There's somebody out there I don't need to see.  You got a fire escape or anything?
No.  What's wrong with the front?
You got a back door to this place?
Yeh, sleepin'.
You doin' anything tonight?
What time you get off work here?
Sixty-five.
Meat loaf, apple pie and a cup of coffee.
I don't know.  Depends what train I get on.
Where you goin'?
She don't work here no more.  I'm fillin' in for a couple days... till I can get a train outa here.
Where's June today?
It isn't any better.
Yeh, I guess I shoulda had the meat loaf.
You done?
Well we can't talk in here.  They're having the place painted.
I thought it might be good for him to see the setup.
What the hell's the matter with you. We coulda met at a club or somethin'.
Les, I got Mr. Lonnegan with me. He wants to see you a second.
Okay, Tootsie.
Tomorrow, after 4:00.  Stay inside, I'll come in and get ya.  And be hard on him for a while; he's talking money.
All right, when?
Twist?  I told him the tale.  He wants to see ya.
No.  They're just the only ones we know of.
You sure it'll be one of these two?
Three grand on the black, Jimmy.
Aw, come on, Hooker, why don't you just...
I feel lucky tonight.
You sure you wanna start off that big?  Bet like that could put a real dent in us.
You gonna have a go here?  How 'bout a ten spot on the line here.  The 4-9 been lookin' good today.  Lotsa action on 28th Street down there, too.  Pay ya 10-1.
Naw, just a little hard times, that's all.  It's all over now.
Ain't seen you in months, boy. Thought maybe you took a fall.
How ya doin', Jimmy.
Hooker!
I don't know, figure something out.
How am I gonna do that?
Tell your friend I'll have the money here by post-time tomorrow. We'll take the first race where the odds are 4-1 or better.  And make sure I can get to that window this time.
Oh, Jesus.
I didn't get the bet down in time.
What happened?
He's right, Les.
A week's a long time, friend. Anything can happen.  All of it bad.
Had a little fight with a raggle down on 13th.  She got me with her ring.
What happened to your face?
You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law.  C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out.
No.
Let me talk to him.
I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much.
If your system's as foolproof as you say, you'll get even more.
What is this?  That's my money. You tryin' to muscle me?
I think we oughta place another bet tomorrow.
Not yet, but...  Hey, there's only a grand here.
You got the 400 grand yet?

It's foolproof.  We got a partner downtown runs the central office of the Western Union.  Race results from all over the country come in there and go right across his desk on their way to the bookies.  All he does in hold them up a couple minutes until he can call us and get a bet down on the winner.  Then he releases the results to the bookies and we clean up on a race that's already been run.  It can't miss, unless the Western Union Dicks get onto it.
I'm in.
You stayin' in or not?
You got a system, Carver?
'Cause it's better to do it all at once.  We're puttin' down 400 grand next week.  At 5-1 we make 2 million. Twenty per cent of that is yours if ya stick with us.
Why don't ya then.
Lucky, hell.  I could do it every day.
You're a lucky man, all right.
Well, what did I tell ya?
Give 'em a little time.
You really picked a winner, kid.
I am after this race.
And you were gonna pay me back?
This is just a test.  The big one comes later.  Be careful with that though, it's all I got.
You're not gonna break him with a $2,000 bet.

Sometime after 1:00 a guy's gonna call here and give you the name of a horse.  All you do is take this two grand across the street to Shaw's place and bet it on that pony.  There's nothin' to it, but don't take too much time.  We only have 3 or 4 minutes after you get the call.
Get on with it then.
I was afraid you weren't gonna come. We haven't got much time.
You should always look to the back too, kid.
If I'm not there by quarter of, I'm not coming.
660 Marshall Street.  Tomorrow at 12:30, if you're interested.
You're dreamin', kid.
Maybe a couple million.
That's worth fifteen grand to ya?
If you help me out, I'll pay ya back the money you owe Shaw, myself.
All you gotta do is place a bet for me at Shaw's place.  I'll supply all the money and the information.
I'm a banker, friend.  That's legit in this state.
I need somebody respectable...but not completely legit.  What I'm gonna do isn't very legal.
Why me?  Shaw probably has lotsa enemies to choose from.
All right, then.
Naw, he picked up some jane in the bar.  Can't see him till morning anyway.
What's the matter?  You gotta get back to Shaw?
Cause I'm tired of bein' his nigger.  I want you to help me break him.
Then why the rat?
So could Shaw.
I could have you put under this train for this, errand boy.
You were set up, Lonnegan.  Shaw's been planning to beat your game for months.  He was just waiting for you to cheat him so he could clip ya.
He hired a dame to take it from ya.
What do you mean?
Yeh, he knows that.
He'll have to take a check.  I couldn't find my wallet.
He cheats.
Your boss is quite a card player, Carver.  How does he do it?
Just as long as I get to finish the play.
All right, Hooker, but you take it on the lam, and we'll shoot you down on sight.
I mean completely played.  Until he's beat and the score is taken. You come in before we beat him and I'll kill him.  You'll have a tough time explaining that, won't ya.
Hell yes.  We don't care about the mark.  He deserves what he gets.
Will you wait until the chump is played?

Like hell.  You won't even get a review till you're seventy.  And if the board starts to go soft, we'll let ya out in the yard some night with a hard-nose young bull who'll put fifty slugs in your face and ask what you were doin' there later.
I'll make parole.
You've already done time twice, and judges don't like three time losers. You wanna sit in the can for forty years, startin' tonight?
No.

Look, I got nothin' against you, but you're in trouble here.  All you gotta do is tell us when Gondorff's gonna play his chump. We come in at the sting, make the pinch, and you walk out free as a bird.  No questions, no court appearance, nothing.
We'll get it, and if we can't, we'll just make it up.  Grand larceny, extortion.  Counterfeiting, anything you want.
You got nothin' on me.
Lt. Snyder doesn't know shit.
Well give yourself a couple seconds, crumb.  You wouldn't wanna lie to me.  Lt. Snyder here says you done a lotta griftin' in this town.
Don't think I know him.
We want to talk to ya about Henry Gondorff.
No.
You want a drink or something?
On the nose!  I said place.  Place it on Syphon.  That horse is going to run second.
Take it easy.  Everything's all right.  I put it on Syphon, on the nose.
Not if you want me to keep makin' 'em for ya.
Yeh, and what if we play tomorrow and he doesn't come up with the money.  We risk our whole operation for nothing.  I'll say when we make our bets.
With 20% coming off the top for me laying your bet.  Either way you end up with 40.
We were getting 50 from our guy.
If it works again tomorrow, I'll have a half million in cash here by noon the next day.  We split 60-40.
On a 6-1 shot?  The hell with ya. We'll keep the deal we got.
I need more proof, that's all. Anybody can get lucky once.
But who says you will.  I got a guy I can depend on.  He's liquidating everything he has for this.  You wouldn't even give Carver his money back.
I could come up with 750 grand in a day if I had a reason to.
Can't do it.  There're telegraph inspectors all over the place.  I got 750 grand coming in from the coast, and I'm not gonna blow it for a lousy 14 gees.  We'll get somebody else to do our betting.
All right, get outa here.  You're outta work.
I don't know.  He took it hard.
Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?
There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up.
You weren't hired to miss him.
We missed him.
All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?
Never heard of the place.
This is the last time I expect to see you down here.
Only rents by the month.  Two hundred and fifty for the two of them.
I'll need a room over there that faces this way.  How much a week?
For fifteen years.
We'll take it.  You manage the building at the end of the alley?
I think he will.
He'll never do it.
He's gonna set up Gondorff for us.
What the hell good is Hooker to ya?

Don't crack wise to me, flatfoot. I spent a lotta time in dumps like this, eatin' Gondorff's dust while the bunco squad gets rich tippin' him off.  But it's not gonna happen this time.  We're not even gonna let the police know we're here.  If you keep your mouth shut and do a job, there'll be a promotion in it for ya.  And you better take it, cause I can make ya work for us without it.
Wouldn't that be too bad.  You'd hafta move outa this nice office ya got.
Cause the stoolies are used to street dicks jumpin' him.  If word gets around that Feds are in on it too, Gondorff'll fold up the whole thing.
Why don't you pick him up yourself?

What is it, madame?

Yes--uh--
Has Mademoiselle Gautier gone?

Oh, M'sieu Laval ...
Jacques!
You know what Paris is saying about the Countess Falconier and her chauffeur?
He is my secretary! I hope that answers all your questions, M'sieu Giron.
Madame, let me ask you: Who is M'sieu Laval, anyhow? Where does he come from? What is he?
I know!
Madame Colet, I've enjoyed the confidence of your family for more than forty years.  I was a school friend of your husband's ...
To M'sieu Laval?
I'm sorry, madame, but there are still certain matters which I think you should attend to yourself. And I, personally, would not care to refer them to--to--
But my dear M'sieu Giron, I'm having a tea party. Must I be bothered with all these papers now?
I don't want your money!
Mademoiselle Gautier--or whatever your name is--I thank you for your advice, but I must ask you to go. You've got your money--
Let me give you a little advice. When you embrace him, be sure to put on your gloves. It would be too bad if your fingerprints were found ...
I beg your pardon!
Ever had a romance with a crook?
I think you'd better go.
Oh, madame, you're just too sweet for words!
Well, in times like these most people are cutting salaries, but suppose we say, in your case, three hundred and fifty?
How much is your salary?
Yes, madame?
Very well, madame. Thank you.

Oh, no, no, no, no, my dear child! That's ridiculous. You go home as usual--five o'clock every day. Now I'm going to be a little bit of a tyrant--I insist. It'll be nice for your little brother, too. <u>Five</u> <u>o'clock</u>--remember!
I'll do my best, madame, even if I have to work every night.
Right!
For all the really important things--
Yes! And he would have a little more time for--
So he wouldn't be confined so much to his office--
No, he <u>works</u> too much.  He's chained to his desk. Too much detail. Now, if you could take over some of his work--
Nervous?  Um-hum. He smokes too much!
To me he seems rather nervous.
Well--uh--yes and no.
Now. Uh--mademoiselle--in the short time you have been M'sieu Laval's secretary, have you noticed any change in him?
Naturally not!
Potatoes. He doesn't want me to eat them--  and naturally I don't want to upset him.
About what?
You see--  Oh, not a word to M'sieu Laval!
Yes, madame?
May I?
Please!  Thank you.
Two lumps, madame?
Yes, that's the trouble with mothers. First you get to like them and then they die.
Yes, madame. You see, I have to get up very early.  My little brother goes to school--  You see, Mother is dead.
You've had your breakfast--oh, but of course you have.

But you saw it here.

Apparently not. Don't you know where it is?
Didn't you take it with you?

Your bag?

Because I hate him--because I love you!

Five compartments. She can stay afloat with the first four compartments breached. But not five. Not five. As she goes down by the head the water will spill over the tops of the bulkheads... at E Deck... from one to the next... back and back. There's no stopping it.
That's right.
Water 14 feet above the keel in ten minutes... in the forepeak... in all three holds... and in boiler room six.
And to you, Mr. Andrews.
Good luck to you, Rose.
I'm sorry that I didn't build you a stronger ship, young Rose.

Hurry, Rose.
Bottom, left, right. I have it.
Take the elevator to the very bottom, go left, down the crewman's passage, then make a right.

What? You have to get to a boat right away!
Mr. Andrews, thank God! Where would the Master at Arms take someone under arrest?!
Yes, I understand. Thank you.

About half, actually. Rose, you miss nothing, do you? In fact, I put in these new type davits, which can take an extra row of boats here.  But it was thought... by some... that the deck would look too cluttered. So I was over-ruled.

Lewis...

We've put together the world's largest database on the Titanic. Okay, here...

Okay, so she's a very old goddamned liar. I traced her as far back as the 20's... she was working as an actress in L.A. An actress. Her name was Rose Dawson. Then she married a guy named Calvert, moved to Cedar Rapids, had two kids. Now Calvert's dead, and from what I've heard Cedar Rapids is dead.
A hundred and one next month.
She says she's Rose DeWitt Bukater, right? Rose DeWitt Bukater died on the Titanic. At the age of 17. If she'd've lived, she'd be over a hundred now.
Get that outta my face.

Shit.

That's the shape my hand's gonna be when I hold that thing. You understand? I'm not leaving here without it.

Lizzy... you gotta understand something. I've bet it all to find the Heart of the Ocean. I've got all my dough tied up in this thing. My wife even divorced me over this hunt. I need what's locked inside your grandma's memory.  You see this? Right here?
I'm not going to help you browbeat my hundred and one year old grandmother. I came down here to tell you to back off.

I put the diamond in my coat pocket. And I put my coat... on her.

The one on the other side is letting men in.

She knows.

That's right. Two things dear to me have disappeared this evening. Now that one is back...  ...I have a pretty good idea where to find the other.  Search him.

I'm not some foreman in your mills than you can command! I am your fiancee --

I see you had that undertaker of a manservant follow me.

The Heart of the Ocean. Cal, it's... it's overwhelming.

Diamond. Yes it is. 56 carats.

Rose is displeased. Mmm... what to do?

What made you think you could put your hands on my fiancee?! Look at me, you filth! What did you think you were doing?!

Good. Settled then.

Smell ice, can you? Bleedin' Christ!

Well I can.

Of course I leave it to your good offices to decide what's best, but what a glorious end to your last crossing if we get into New York Tuesday night and surprise them all.  Retire with a bang, eh, E.J.?

So you've not lit the last four boilers then?
I promise. I will never let go, Jack. I'll never let go.
Never let go.
I promise.
You must do me this honor... promise me you will survive... that you will never give up... no matter what happens... no matter how hopeless... promise me now, and never let go of that promise.

To the stars.

He's an ex-Pinkerton. Cal's father hired him to keep Cal out of trouble... to make sure he always got back to the hotel with his wallet and watch, after some crawl through the less reputable parts of town...

No wait. Let me try to get this out. You're amazing... and I know I have nothing to offer you, Rose. I know that. But I'm involved now. You jump, I jump, remember? I can't turn away without knowin' that you're goin' to be alright.
Jack, I --
Rose, you're no picnic... you're a spoiled little brat even, but under that you're a strong, pure heart, and you're the most amazingly astounding girl I've ever known and --
I like that. Aren't we supposed to wish on it?
That was a long one. My father used to say that whenever you saw one, it was a soul going to heaven.

A mistake?

Why can't I be like you Jack? Just head out for the horizon whenever I feel like it.  Say we'll go there, sometime... to that pier... even if we only ever just talk about it.
Yeah; it was great money... I could make a dollar a day, sometimes. But only in summer. When it got cold, I decided to go to Paris and see what the real artists were doing.

Well, then logging got to be too much like work, so I went down to Los Angeles to the pier in Santa Monica. That's a swell place, they even have a rollercoaster. I sketched portraits there for ten cents a piece.

I'm sorry. Really... I am.

You wouldn'ta jumped.

Jack.

Well they have some of the coldest winters around, and I grew up there, near Chippewa Falls. Once when I was a kid me and my father were ice- fishing out on Lake Wissota... ice- fishing's where you chop a hole in the --
No.

Nathan Hockley, right. Pittsburgh steel tycoon. For a diamond necklace his son Caledon Hockley bought in France for his fiancee... you... a week before he sailed on Titanic. And the claim was filed right after the sinking. So the diamond had to've gone down with the ship.  See the date?
Someone named Hockley, I should imagine.
I tracked it down through insurance records... and old claim that was settled under terms of absolute secrecy. Do you know who the claiment was, Rose?
It was a dreadful, heavy thing.  I only wore it this once.

Louis the Sixteenth wore a fabulous stone, called the Blue Diamond of the Crown, which disappeared in 1792, about the time Louis lost everything from the neck up. The theory goes that the crown diamond was chopped too... recut into a heart-like shape... and it became Le Coeur de la Mer. The Heart of the Ocean. Today it would be worth more than the Hope Diamond.
I should like to see my drawing.
Would you like anything?
There, that's nice. I have to have my pictures when I travel. And Freddy of course.  Isn't that right, sweetie.
Yes. Very nice. Have you met my granddaughter, Lizzy? She takes care of me.

Goodbye, mother.
Rose, get in the boat!
Of course it's unfair! We're women. Our choices are never easy.

Do you want to se me working as a seamstress? Is that what you want? Do you want to see our fine things sold at an auction, our memories scattered to the winds? My God, Rose, how can you be so selfish?
How can you put this on my shoulders?
I don't understand you. It is a fine match with Hockley, and it will insure our survival.
Your father left us nothing but a legacy of bad debts hidden by a good name. And that name is the only card we have to play.

Baloney!

And when you do I'll convey your respects by wireless to Herbert.  Take it easy, Lee--no other woman'll ever get you. At least I'm honest when I tell you there must be something pretty low down in me--because I like you.  You're such a swine!
--and I can tell you where to get off.
Oh--a hundred times--

Just make it as difficult as possible for you to see her.

When I found out you were going I just had an attack of nerves--a few tears--and Herbert was on his way downtown to get my passport ... so who cares ... I'm here with you ... and that's all that matters to me.

It would be a nice change from you.
Do you want the truth, Anya?

Anya, I think you're crazy.

Anya!

Yes--and <U>very</U> popular--

Good afternoon--

--that's what we call double-a grade lumber, ma'am; You don't find a knot in a thousand feet.

Montana?

Get moving--

I'll lay odds you get a pair of 'em--Why, a high-school kid could take you saps--and another thing--Lay off Sally Marsh.  --"Honest Jack"! One look at your mug and the whole world buttons up its pockets.

Aces full.

Jimmy!

Good night, Mrs. Brett!

What?--

Lonesome?

--I know what I'm talking about. I'm no high-school girl looking through a window--reaching for the moon.  Guess I'll be going.
But--

Thanks.

A little.

--you want to adopt him!--Good for you!

So you washed it off!

--You'll have all the boys tipping their hats to you--  --let me wipe it off.

Very much--
Like her paint job?
Yes--
Nice lines--

On the drunk.

Inspector McKinney.

A thousand? She's one in a million--right off the top of the rosebush!
--there's thousands of 'em!
Oh, Shortie!--  --there's a girl on this ship--

Not a chance.
I'll need it--gave my last buck to the bedroom steward.
A dollar forty.
How're the tips?

You don't think--?
Shortie, look!
You're a wise guy--Gimme back--

If I was smart I wouldn't be working my way over on this ship.
I thought you were a smart guy.

Much better--thank you--

It's your deal.
That beats two Pairs. I'm glad <U>I</U> didn't win the first pot. Take the money, Mr. Brett.
Three Jacks.

Come in!

Why, I--

Nice girl, that--  I'd hate to see <U>her</U> get a raw deal.  You know, the great trouble with crooks is they're <U>too</U> smart. Now if I'd taken that bracelet, I'd find some way to slip it back--I'd know I could never get ashore with it.

Wouldn't bet against her.  Tell you what I will do--bet you I find that bracelet before we hit France.  Not a hundred, though--just fifty.

I'll go with you.

Women are such fools!--Why do so many of us pass up <U>right</U> guys?
I'll never love anybody else.
Come on, now--you've forgotten all about that.
But not nice enough to marry--eh?
Chad Denby broadcasting--  --the nicest man I ever knew--
Stay on the other side of the pond for a couple of months--you'll soon forget all about it.
Women have a curious taste for knickknacks. When I found out about Ned--tried to make a break--Lee wouldn't stand for it and--well--here I am!
I felt pretty low, Sally, when I heard you were running around with a racketeer--

I was so crazy about him--anything he did or said was O.K. by me.  I introduced him to people--even after I knew his stock promoting was phoney and the card games were crooked. It didn't seem to matter--I didn't care--  --until he roped Ned in. Some confidence game--and the kid left his fingerprints on a drinking glass.
I get it--Lee Lother have a hand in that, too?
It wasn't only that--Ned was in a jam.
News travels fast on Broadway--you had to get away from a rat--
You made it possible for us to get away at a few hours' notice--you never asked why, but I guess you know.
Do what--
I came to tell you what a swell guy I think you are to do this--
No--Inexperienced--  A red-headed kid--homemade clothes--Broadway was Paradise--and a slot at the Automat was a Banquet.
Still got my picture, I see--I was pretty dumb then, wasn't I, Chad?
No--not much--excepting--
You never fail at anything, do you, Chad?
Why not? I give 'em a great show--and you know-- We're doing capacity, Sally--and all <U>Nice</U> people--
And you've put it over--haven't you?
Yep--spending lots of time aboard--you see, Sally, I sold this Transatlantic idea to the shipping company.
Swell--You've got Times Square right here--all but the noises--
Like it?
Looks like your old workshop back on 42nd Street.
Just what the doctor ordered.
Everything O.K.?
Are you paying any attention to his jokes?--the first thing you know, you'll be taking piano lessons from Venus de Milo--  Get out of here.
You're the President. Come in! Your brother was just telling me a few jokes I can use on the radio--
Am I a member of this club?
Will be--as soon as the ship sails.
Are you happy?
Well, that's something--even if only the fish can see it.
You don't shoot squirrels.

Why don't you be a good little boy and leave her alone?

Good-night, folks.
Oh, Mr. Denby, I wrote a poem about a bracelet--
Oh,--I was having so much fun I almost forgot--
Oh, Chad--what about the rest of the show?
Oh, all right--  See you later, Toots.
H'mm ... no wonder I have trouble rounding up this show--Don't you know there's a rehearsal going on?-- And you wanted a raise.--Come on--get going or you'll get it!
No--He's probably one of the "Here's How."  Take it easy--the ocean's pretty rough today--
Is that one of the Who's Who?
Don't blame it on the ocean!--All right, you'll get the raise!
Never mind the Who's Who--Before I get on this boat I want to know What's What! How about my raise? All I get out of these ocean trips is dizzy.
All right--don't spoil the trip with any of those jokes-- there's a nice bunch of people on this trip--nothing but class--I looked over the passenger list and they're all members of the Who's Who!
Get that out of your trunk.

--And he has sex appeal.

With your dry wit and humor--
Mary--fall off the boat and turn to the left--
When it falls off the table and turns turtle--Cute?

Then, after the first number, I tell the one about the Scotchman trying to open a Pullman window--the Scotchman says to the window--"Gee you're tight."-- and the window says--"You loosen up a bit and so will I."--Good?--And then I do the one--  Oh--you don't like it, eh?

There's a lot of trout in this stream just waitin' for a fly.  I've already been workin' on a young fellow from Chicago--related to one of the big packin' families--on his way to Biarritz for a good time. Likes a little game of bridge and poker.

Have you ever figured they might extradite you?

I've lost my taste for knickknacks--

Let's see if I can bring it back to life.

--and you swear when you get to the other side, you'll never come near either of us again?
Just smile again and be reasonable.  I'll order dinner here--just the two of us--like old times.
I'm crazy about the kid and I got him into it.  What do you want me to do?

--you'd go with him!
A tipoff in the right quarter to take his fingerprints and--

Thanks to me.

You get wise to <U>yourself</U>! If you know what's good for you, you'll leave me alone. Everybody's entitled to one mistake--Well--you're mine. When the going got too rough, I pulled up stakes and quit. We stay quit!--Get that!--And what're you going to do about it?
Get wise to yourself, Sally--you're no sob story.
I wish I could.
Because I want you--will always want you--no other woman'll ever take your place.  I want you more now than I did that first night--  You've forgotten all that, I suppose?
Why don't you leave me alone?
It wasn't smart. Even if you'd gotten away without me --I'd have found you--no matter where you were.
I didn't want to see you again--that's my privilege.
You ran away because you were afraid. I don't want it to end like that.
All right--but what is there to face? It's finished.

Why?

You didn't have a gun in your hand last night?

He's a swell person. He told me he'd rather turn one guy straight than jug a million.
Next time I get a vacation I'll spend it at headquarters. Good-night.

He tied one on.

You too.

Here. I gave you my assistant's phone number. If it's urgent, she knows where to reach me.

No.

Happily.
Married?
Depends what number you write.

Of course.

They point, I shoot.

Interesting presentation.
Now.

If you think we're going to have some kind of 'life affirming' romance here just because we cheated death, let me be clear:  We're going to have it where I want, and when I want.

We blast through.

You insist on calling all the shots.  And by the way: I am not a helpless girl.

It's a lousy job, but -  The only reason I stay is for the health benefits.

Sometimes you just have to -

Put your arms around my neck. Lock your legs around my waist.

Up.

Blood or Dutch?

Harmsway sank that ship and stole the gold. It's on the Sea Dolphin II.  And thanks to your little show and tell -  - giving him the evidence -  We're the only ones who can tie him to the crime.
Listen to me! I'm a British secret service agent. And we have about two minutes before Harmsway kills both of us.

- You're not.

- The family jewels?

I hope so.

So charming! So suave!  Don't insult me. I'm not one of your 'little London girls' who falls for the lies.

No?
You have to excuse Miss Winch: She thinks she's on a 'seduce and destroy' mission through life...  ...But she won't kill us.
- Shut up!

Nice to run into you again.

I'll keep that in mind.

Insurance. Lloyds of London.

Actually, I'm here on business. You might say it was a... Golden opportunity.
So what brings you to Kuala Lumpur, Mr. Bond?  Wait - don't tell me: Unhappy marriage? Running from some poor little girl with two kids and a Chanel pocketbook in - London?
Pity.  Bring him whatever he wants.

Boyfriend?

- And I bet you always leave turmoil in your wake.

Bourbon. Neat.

We serve the interests of the British people, 007. No matter who we may be foolish enough to elect.
.... I hate to ask, but... Did you ever think you'd miss Communism?
I understand.

Sakwa!

Ja-shwa tsway. These are lips.
... And what do you call these?
Good-day, Miss Winch. I advise you to get some steam up - before you run aground.
You won't get away with this!
You leave me no alternative.
No.
Hmmm. I suppose this is a step above that profession.  Ten seconds. Are you leaving?
I was an attorney!
Fifteen seconds. Perhaps you should consider hiring an attorney.

Good for you, Miss Winch. You now have exactly 30 seconds to get this rust bucket out of here.
My name is Sidney Winch, and -
Captain Morton.

I am. What do you want?
Who's in charge here?

Your bankers want an answer about the Brazilian TV stations
Send him a $10,000 campaign contribution, and explain I have no control over what my journalists write -

Pencil it in for the next trip -
The Canadian Prime Minister wants to set a lunch -
Chew up a log like that in the propeller, you end up with enough paperwork to go from here to London. Twice.

A dead head.  Water logged timber. Floats straight up. You sometimes see them on the east side of the channel - from the logging camps on Sumatra - but they don't usually float this far west.  Muncy! Engines to half!

How is it now?
Check it again. What about the global positioning satellite? Could there be something wrong with the signal?

- I told you! He was there! -
Obviously, the British government denies all of this -

A hundred and fifty years ago, my ancestors took this island - a barren, lifeless rock - and turned it into the greatest city known to modern civilization. You have to leave -

- Built to withstand a nuclear blast.  Are they alive?

Fueled and waiting.

Here I am thinking about myself when poor Harry is resting on the floor of the kitchen.

How come you're not wearing my shoes?
Yes.

Oh here we go with that.
Junior spends time with his child.
Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.

No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.
Why, you don't want us to bring him over?
We got the same thing.
What did your wife get her?
I hadn't forgotten. I ordered some cloth but it didn't come in and I felt so bad if I would have come to her birthday without that, I just stayed at home.
Your mother asked me not to mention it but your mother's birthday was last week.

I pay my own way.
That's a lie.

What time is it? Do you think you can just treat us like your slave? It's after one.
What is it, noontime?
I'm cold. I need to get out into the sunlight.
We will take her. You all stay here and watch Dad.
I'll drive her to the hospital.
My name is Sam. Samuel.
You dumb ass, it's Babe Brother.
I'm leaving and don't even call me when the shoe falls 'cause all he did for me was to try and run my life. I'm tired of people saying Babe Brother this, Babe Brother that. What's my name?
I ought to break your damn neck.

I told you about calling me boy. I ain't no boy. See, you and Dad got a bad habit of calling me boy. You call me boy in front of my wife. You think I'm going to fix the roof? I hope the wind blows the whole damn thing off and it pours down rain.

That is a damn lie and you know it. Every time father asks you to do something, you either half-ass do it or run off and hide. Mama asked you to turn the dirt in her garden and you told her, with your smart ass self, that you weren't a farmer; get Junior to do it. Every time someone asks you to do something, you always say, tell Junior to do it. Boy, you ought to grow up.
You always got the best of it around here and when Dad always talks about my son, it is always you, so you fix the roof.
I bet you if your master would have told you to fix the hole in the roof, you would have rebuilt the whole damn house.
I told her I would if she would give me time.
Why in the hell didn't you help mama?
Maybe I can get down there next week.
Robert asks about you. When are you going to do something to help him?
This is what it is all about, trying to keep from being out on the street.
This is not a good time to take chances. Your best friend, Robert, an accountant, lost his home and is out on the street. We see him from time to time. He comes down to church for a free meal.
Why are you always afraid to get somewhere?
You want me to mortgage my house to invest in a scheme of yours? You know the last time we went into something together Daddy had to go in his savings to keep us from ending on the street.
You always got something to say.
You used that excuse to get out of the army.
You all don't believe me when I tell you I'm afraid of heights.
When are you going to find time to help me fix the roof?
I guess it proves you really care about me. You hung in there.
And what lesson have we learned from all of this, Babe Br... Sam... I mean Samuel?
It was nip and tuck.
Do you think you won?
I couldn't believe the things I was doing. It was like an internal struggle going on inside my body.
You were in hell?

Like muddy waters?
It's like I've been swimming in muddy waters.
Like a veil has been lifted?
I have more sense than to give up everything, my family, you and Sunny. It wasn't me, I mean the real me inside my body. I'm glad it's over. It's like a veil has been lifted.
I'm okay. Go back to your friends.
You okay?
Why in the h...
Linda, how come you don't see that Sunny puts his shoes on right?
I don't need that kind of love. And I don't want to be reminded all the time that Big Mama's grandmother was born in slavery. If you really care about me, just tell me how I can make money.
He is just being like all parents, concerned about the ones they love.
Why does he always pick on me?
I preached to Mom and Dad about it but they are stuck in their ways, it's like talking to a brick. But if there is a way...
We could borrow on that land and put the money to work.
Pops put Big Daddy's farm in Rhonda's and Sunny's name and fixed it so no one can borrow on it.
I told him we might not need it, if you can talk your parents into giving you your share of the property.
Will you still get the money from your father?
You would think people never lived in a house if they have to ask what does 1 1/2 baths mean.

I would like to finish reading this. What would I talk about? I haven't read this month's almanac. I don't care to hear about how the corn was this fall or how to get rid of gophers by putting garlic in their holes. They pride themselves in making life hard and that's not my cup of tea.
Why don't you come in for a while?
How old are you?
I don't see you crying about my drinking it.
Coffee is bad for anybody, especially for a child.
What is a sip of coffee going to do?
I want Sunny to have an advantage that you and I never had, but he needs discipline, and you are not helping when I tell him to do something and you allow him to get out of it.

My daddy never gave me anything without my having to sweat for it. Every summer, the way they kept me and Junior out of trouble was to send us to Big Daddy's farm. We would get up with the chickens. Every summer the fence had to be repaired. The barn needed a coat of paint. We had to pip all of Big Mama's hundred laying hens and go to church all day on Sunday. For Big Daddy, calluses and sweat were the mark of a man. Sunny will never have to bust his knuckles like we did.
Because you were spoiled, don't try to spoil Sunny.

I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  You sit right there with your no manners self.
Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.
Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.
I'm busy.
Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.
Harry is coming to pick me up.
I've heard some foolish things in my life.
I'm going back home with Harry.
What for?

Well, you look better than you did yesterday.
Doesn't he look a whole of lot better?
He will be alright.
This doesn't make any sense; you are going to drag that poor boy out in the cold air.
I was hoping you came to the door instead of him. It gets cold at night.
Babe Brother.
Who is it?
We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra?  Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up.  What would you give to be rich?
This would be a bad time for me to leave.
I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time.

It is just a regular card.
Never play with someone's else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this card. See anything?
Boy, that is the real South. That is real corn liquor.
